reviews: A quintessential and popular Biergarten in the heart of the Munich city center, I had to stop here even knowing that everyone else who is traveling to Munich also feels the same way. I had to, and I'm so glad that I did. First off...THIS PLACE IS HUGE!  The famous HB Hofbrauhaus is an icon when it comes to drinking (and eating) establishments in Munich. One of the six breweries in the metro Munich area, its beer did not disappoint. A steady stream of customers continued to file in but nobody was walking out. In an hour the capacity of folks inside doubled. We sat down about 11am and only waited about 4-5 mins for a server to greet us. A one liter beers seem large and they are! But, cmon....you have to. And, so we did. Two 1liter original HB cold brews!  We also grabbed a Luke warm pretzel and shared an order of weisswurst (a traditional morning food for Germans) since it was before noon. The sausage was amazing. Subtle hints of seasoning in a ground veal white sausage in a firm casing. The pretzel was a combination of soft and chewy in the thicker parts with a nice brown salty crust and crunchy thin areas. And of course the beer tasted way better than our American brews. My suggestion is to definitely visit here. But get here early as from what I saw and heard, if you wait too long, you'll be standing. And beware. Certain tables have signs over them which denote them  as a "locals" table and they have certain rights to the table. I'm not sure that they would kick you out, but they do have "dibs."Prost!
Awesome medieval tavern vibe. Delicious sausages and refreshing beers. The waitresses will yell at you if you order something nonalcoholic lol. Grab a seat and immerse yourself!Highly recommended!

Visiting the Hofbräuhaus while in Munich is definitely at the top of the list for classic German beer and fare. It's bustling and warm feeling inside, like you are being welcomed home whether you're German or just a tourist!The Hofbräuhaus is famed as the world's most famous tavern. I'm sure it is ridiculously busy during Oktoberfest and other event times in Germany. We happened to go in April, and it was still busy, but not crazy at all, and we got a table to sit at and were greeted by our server right away.The decor is definitely old world and classic with heavy wooden booths and tables, as well as cream colored ceilings and columns painted with faded murals and the iconic blue and white checkered flag of Bavaria. The beer is obviously brewed by the Hofbräu state brewery, and their brews can be purchased all over the world (the iconic blue "HB" logo is what you look for), but that is nothing like getting it right from the source at the Hofbräuhaus!We stuck with the giant Hofbräu Original mugs (they were the size of my head!). It was surprisingly light in body and had a slight floweriness in the finish, making it super easily drinkable even though it came in the giant mugs.My travel partner and I also nibbled on a few of the food offerings, to complement our giant beers (and not to drink on an empty stomach!)I had the Beef Goulash that came in a hot cast iron skillet of sauce with perfectly cooked little bits of beef marinating inside, and accompanied by a little bread dumpling (that almost looked like mashed potatoes at first!) My friend got the giant baked pretzel, but we forgot to snap a pic - just trust me, it was wonderful.This is for sure a spot you should stop at in Munich for the history, the food, and of course, the beer!

Came here for a beer and had a great experience! I had a .5 L of the dark beer which was great. The space is huge, there's a small stage for a band, and tons of tables but note, it's community seating. There's also a gift shop here. Stopping here for a beer is a must while in Munich. Service here was great, as our waiter was very attentive and prompt, despite the place being at capacity with visiting British soccer fans.

A must visit when in Munich.  Part of a chain, this original location is a very festive beer hall and is a great way to experience the German drinking culture.  Get the   pretzel, pork knuckle and liter of the beer of choice and you're set!
Don't go for the food. Go for the experience and ambience. Service was excellent. Bring a gallon of water with you as food is really salty.

When I saw the big sign Hofbrauhuas, I couldn't move my legs, I got to drink a cup of beer here. The place is huge with courtyard and 3 floors, that's why we waited for a while to get service. You can sit wherever you find seats. The beer was not disappointing, I loved the atmosphere more than food, we ordered sausage platter, which is nice companion for beer. Live music was in the house to make drinking more pleasant. I feel totally relaxed and could easily spend whole day here. There are lockers for regulars to be able to lock their favorite fancy beer cups with seats.

The service was great! Our hostess was dressed in traditional German attire (Dirndl) and was friendly, bonus she spoke English. She provided English menus that had traditional German dishes. The venue is a big permanent beer hall. As we left, some musicians showed up and started warming up. Parking is a bit of a challenge, but this place is worth it! Highly recommend!!

A must stop when in Munich even if it is packed and a little touristy. We got lucky and grabbed a table just as people were leaving it. Shortly after 4 people asked to share the table. It was great, we are American and they were all from London here for the Arsenal game.

A true classic. Definitely a must visit place, really busy but really cool. We were there Krampusnacht so that could contribute to how busy it was on a Monday. Service honestly good too, people were saying it was bad but never had an issue. Real good beer and classic kind of heavy but tasty German food. If I find myself in Munich again (I sure hope I do!) I'd go back.

A huge german restaurant with a beautiful ceiling and wall mural art, live traditional music and huge family style tables. Unfortunately, I came here on a Saturday around 8pm and it was so packed it took about 30 minutes for my party of 6 to split up to hunt down a table. Once we did it took another 30 minutes to forceably get a servers attention to get us menus. It was like another 15 minutes to get our orders taken and an additional 45 minutes to an hour to get our food. Yup, that bad. Thankfully my party was super easy going and able to keep ourselves entertained. The pros is that the restaurant has a man walking around selling pretzels so we definitely got some to hold us up with all the waiting around for menus and our ordered food. The pretzel was good but would be much better with mustard. Good luck getting that. That took us about 20 minutes to ask a server for that after we got our pretzels. Our pretzel was almost completely devoured by then. Besides the pretzels, the food we ordered was tasty. I ordered the roast chicken, potatoes and pickled red cabbage - it was good.

Our group of 10 was able to sit upstairs where it's a bit more conducive to conversation. The beers flow nice and service is quick. Had the roast pork and crackling in a dark beer gravy which was more like a broth. Switched out the potato dumpling for spaetzle. Hubby had the pike perch. HB is somewhere every visitor should experience.

We got off our train in Munich, and my husband dragged us to Hofbrauhaus - which turned out to be his mothership. I saw a genuine smile on him for the first time in two weeks. It was an upbeat place that was beautiful inside. It's huge! We sat inside just a couple of tables from the polka band, and it was really fun. I can imagine this place could get super loud when packed, but it wasn't bad when we were right when they opened at 11 am. He had a couple of beers and discovered beer fills him up much faster than when he was 23. He wished he'd tried a few smaller beers rather than go for one big one that immediately filled him up. Our daughter had the strawberries and cream, which I'm sure was good, but I can't vouch for it since she wouldn't let me get a forkful. And while the radish/chive/bread sounds rather dull, I loved it. Dense bread with a white creamy butter and chives was tastier than you might guess. I also love all the radish dishes in this country; they don't have the spicy flavor we are used to in the States. Of course, we also had pretzels, which are harder and crunchier than a Wetzel's Pretzel of the same size. Try both mustards that come with it, I thought the sweet one was flavorful even though I'm usually picky about mustards.

We were so excited to eat at the infamous Hofbrauhaus! We made a reservation, and got a nice little table on the 2nd floor. They had live music! Every part of the experience was great. It's a must-see spot for great food and even better beer. The first floor is the traditional open seating style, so it was fun to see it busy and loud! Great gift shop too.

If you're looking to feel like you're at Oktoberfest when you either A) don't want to go to Oktoberfest or B) aren't in Munich during Oktoberfest, this is probably your best bet. This location is huge and there is seating on multiple levels. We stuck to the first floor because we liked the vibe, but it's not for everyone. Apparently you can find quieter tables upstairs, but just go in knowing that it will probably be crowded and energetic on the first floor.After you find a spot, you wait for a server to come by to take your meal order. If you'd like a pretzel or a cookie, you call over one of the people walking around with them and pay them cash. As a foreigner to Germany, I felt the food was decent. Someone from Germany might feel this is likened to Applebee's or something, but I didn't take issue with any of the dishes. We ordered a pretzel, a half chicken, the sausage plate, and the Spätzle. While the Spätzle and sausages were okay, the chicken was really tasty and I enjoyed this the most. It was so tender and not dry whatsoever, and although it wasn't heavily seasoned, it was well-cooked. The pretzel was also fine, but you can definitely get a better one elsewhere. We started off the trip slow with half-liters of beer here, but like many places in Munich, you have the option of a half or a whole liter. A band plays somewhere near the middle of the room, so pay attention to where you sit if you don't like loud sounds near your head.

Hofbräuhaus in Munich, Germany, is a quintessential Bavarian experience that transports you to the heart of traditional German hospitality - it left me with a hearty dose of good food, lively vibes, and an overall positive impression.The star of the show was undoubtedly the roast pork with crackling, a dish that captured the essence of Bavarian culinary excellence. The pork was succulent, and the crackling added a delightful crunch that elevated the experience. Paired with authentic German potato dumpling, it was a comforting and satisfying dish that showcased the rich flavors of Bavarian cuisine.The addition of a bread basket was a pleasant touch, offering an assortment of freshly baked bread that complemented the hearty main course. Additionally, indulging in a pretzel from a roving vendor added an element of fun to the dining experience. The pretzel, with its golden crust and soft interior, was the perfect accompaniment to the lively atmosphere.Speaking of atmosphere, the lively ambiance at Hofbräuhaus is truly something to be celebrated. Live music echoed through the halls, creating a festive atmosphere that beckoned guests to join in the merriment. The communal seating and convivial spirit of the place make it an ideal spot for socializing and immersing oneself in Bavarian culture.The service, while friendly, was a bit on the slower side, and securing a table can be a challenge during peak hours. However, these are minor considerations given the overall charm of the establishment.In conclusion, Hofbräuhaus is a must-visit for those seeking an authentic Bavarian dining experience in Munich. The flavors, atmosphere, and cultural immersion make it a memorable destination - recommend it to anyone looking for a lively taste of traditional German hospitality. Prost!

The beers are refreshing here, full to the brim and in tall, iced glasses. Ordered the HB Bavarian platter with a bread basket and it was enough for lunch. The tables are communal style so you just walk in and sit where you want. The service was a bit slow since they seemed short staffed and were rushing around tables. The entertainment at lunchtime was moderate and muted. The Las Vegas Haufbrahaus was more lively with its passionate band, various beer contests, getting the crowd to sing beer songs, a woman selling shots and spankings, and variety of entertainment acts every week.

Obviously a must go on everyone's Munich itinerary. Huge beer hall with tons of seating. If it happens to be busy you just look around and find a spot at any table. Servers are good and will find you. They take both cash and credit. Went during Oktoberfest time, so was likely more busy then usual. Found a spot right away. Ordered kasespatzle and it was very good. Beer was good. Very lively environment inside with live music. They also have a beer garden. Few different gift shops within the place with all the merch you could want from a beer hall. This place has lots of history and was involved in a lot of historical events. Would be nice to read a little on the history before you go.

I can't speak for the food, because I was here to drink during Oktoberfest. However, a lot of people around me were eating and the food looked fantastic! But, can you really go wrong with meat and potatoes? According to my Polish friend, who has been to Oktoberfest more times than he can count, this is his very favorite place to have beers in the city. I didn't have anything to compare it to, but I was very impressed at how good the service was, considering how packed it was the night we were there. Beers came immediatley. After a long day of flying in from the west coast of the states and walking 10 blocks from our hotel - this place and the giant beers hit the spot.

The hype is real and it sure lives up to it. If you're from the States like me don't think you'll get the table service your used to. This place is so darn busy these servers ain't got time for the jaw jackin or typical niceties you're used to. I respect that and you should too dude/dudet! The beer is amazing here. Just think for a second on why they've been here for so long, but don't think too much because you'll miss the server coming by and you'll need to flag em down and order. Also be sure to order some roast chicken. It's like a rotisserie chicken but 10x better. It'll soak up all the alcohol. Not sure if it's just because I came here for Oktoberfest but they had a live band playing your traditional Bavarian bangers. Puts the vibe all together for one great Beer hall experience. Hoping to come back next year and find the kind strange gentleman who shared our table with a warm pretzel and a smile.

If you come to Munich, and you like beer, then this is a "must stop", simply for the history, if not the atmosphere.In spite of what some may opine, their beer is very good by most any standard, but among regional German breweries they face very stiff competition.The beer hall is loud and touristy, but if you're reading this, you are likely a tourist. So go enjoy yourself. As for comments on cash only, they took my card this afternoon, no problem. Enjoy. Cheers!RS

Had to check out a Munich staple. I was told this place had been around since the 1400's. You can do tours of the old brewery if you book in advance. The location is extremely neat and spacious. Great for groups, although the service is relatively spotty. It can take some time to get served. I highly recommend you stop by for a beer at least, because the venue is beautiful and very unique. It's like stepping back in the past!

Hofbräuhaus MunichAll of God's Children visit Hofbräuhaus Munich.We have arranged for 4 visits over the years.Are you aware of Hitler Connection?Hofbräuhaus is located is in the heart of Munich's old town in Marienplatz, it also hosts the second-largest beer tent at Oktoberfest.Caveat: we recommend that one does not visit Munich and Hofbräuhaus during Octoberfest.Fortunately, many Americans have enjoyed the festivities of Octoberfest, and it is with pleasure and purpose that we visit the several US Hofbräuhaus.We first visited Munich and Hofbräuhaus in 1970's and greatly enjoyed and for years have driven to Waterloo Ontario for world's second largest Octoberfest.Hofbräuhaus provides an older Bavarian experience which many urban Germans do Not identify.What are three of the biggest beer tents at Oktoberfest?Overview of the big tents * Oktoberfest.de - The Official ...The large tents at Oktoberfest    Augustiner Festhalle. Beer from wooden barrels, own butcher's shop. ...    Armbrustschützenzelt. The name says it all - the crossbow tradition lives here. ...    Festzelt Tradition. Celebrate in the Tradition festival tent on the Oide Wiesn. ...    Fischer-Vroni. ...    Hacker-Festzelt.

it's a must do when visiting Munich! no reservations are needed when in smaller groups and they do accept credit cards. The giant pretzel was fantastic and you get that from the girls that come around the tables. Now for those westerners you'll have to understand and be patient when ordering unlike in America people take their time here so enjoy the atmosphere. They are pretty good at getting your beer order in. Keep in mind that this is a communal table so you could be sitting with other people so enjoy and make friends. Have a great beer and enjoy the live music.

Everyone says, "You have to go to this place!" And they're right.This is the largest indoor pub in the world (might not technically be true, but it's huge : )I'm going to give you a very simple review and you can look at my pictures.--the ambiance (5+/5) is out of this world! Long tables, seating as many as a dozen (or more), people cheering, the umpa band playing. So much fun.--the service (4/5) is not bad, considering the mass quantities of people.--the food (2/5). Don't go for the food. I had the veal sausage (2/5), a pretzel (2/5), and apple streusel (3/5).--the beer (4/5) was good. I had a rattler (lemon beer) for the first time and enjoyed it.Highly recommended!

It was very busy and hard to find a table. When we finally did, the Servers were arguing about which of them could take us on. It was uncomfortable. The food was not worth the money, it tasted cheap and was not authentic.I am sorry to give this a low-rating, but that's just how I experienced it the two times I went there. Would not recommend.

If you're searching for a spot that serves genuine German food with a lively atmosphere and excellent service, look no further than Hofbräuhaus. It's definitely a must-visit for anyone wanting to indulge in a slice of Bavaria right here in town. Make sure to try the schnitzel when you visit--you won't be disappointed!

Food 4Service 2Ambiance 5This was so much fun!I finally understood why our beer halls in Milwaukee are the way they are lol. We were there on Wednesday night, and the place was packed to the brim full. You have to find your own seating, and feel free to sit next to other people, since all tables are shared. Getting a table is like war though. not knowing the rules, it took us a while to find out that we had to find our own seats, but after literally standing in front of a server to ask for help, we were told to seat anywhere. After that it was a matter of finding people who were leaving, which we did, but just as we were seating down after a party got up, this one server came barreling down and yelled at us not to sit there. And then, he waved over 4 girls and told them to sit down before us. What's up with selectively finding seats for some customers (coincidentally, all 4 of them looking single in their 20's)?Being swept up in the whole atmosphere, we let that go and just sat down next to the girls. Our table was big enough to sit 8. Being in Germany, I'm wary of making this joke from Frasier, but, have you heard of soup Nazi? Well, our server was a beer Nazi. He refused to serve beers smaller than a liter per person. We were totally fine with that lol, but the 4 girls beside us were all flabbergasted (though still dutifully ordered their 4 liter beers, and then drank maybe about a quarter of each cup before leaving). Our server also acted like he spoke no English, and kept saying something about why he can't bring us smaller beers in German. But when the time came for us to pay our bill, his English improved significantly, started asking us small questions like where we were from all of a sudden, smiled, and told us that tip wasn't included in the bill. And then stay and watch you as you make the payment. The menu says a pretzel is 1.9euros, but they don't sell it. You have to buy it separately from the "bread girl/guy" who comes around with the pretzels in a basket. And they charge 4.2euros. They will also rob you of your change, so count your coins. Or not. Just be a tourist and enjoy the moment and let them have their fun. We walked in knowing it was a tourist trap, as did the 1,000 (or 2) other patrons inside, but it was still all fun and games. The food was actually quite good, the live music was fun, and the atmosphere was bustling with energy. You gotta go at least once!Oh, the food:pretzel - good. But I can proudly say, that the pretzels at beer gardens here in Milwaukee actually top theirs!obazda (cheese spread for the pretzel) - good. Again, Milwaukee, though...four pieces of pork sausage - good, but we had better sausage at every other corner in Germany. Including Norma's. Sauerkraut was delicious! I never liked sauerkraut much, until this visit to Germany. Roasted knuckle of pork - I had this 3 times in Germany, and this one was comparable to the other 2 places. I learned that I love this dish. Beef goulash - it was like tomato soup with huge chunks of steak inside. Overall, I wouldn't go here for a gourmet meal, but for the energy and the pure experience. It's just fun! And maybe if you're single, you can find a table with a bunch of other single and available others to get to know better.

Avoid Sundays... we had such a great time the other day that we came back to Hofbrauhaus on Sunday. What a mistake. It seems like the backup waiters work Sundays. They must draw the short straw. We had M. Sataric today and he was terrible. I know it was only his 4th day, but he mixed up a lot of orders: beers, food, you name it. He brought the wrong thing or nothing at all. And he argued about everything with us... and the table next to us. He also kept disappearing for lengthy periods. It was not crowded, yet service was very slow.

This is one of the few places I've ever been that truly lives up to the hype. It's definitely a must see in Munich, plus the food and drinks are excellent and the service is top notch. Be sure to check out the outdoor beer garden for the full experience. We had a sausage platter, pretzels, and beer which is basically the Bavarian trifecta.

I would say this place is a must. They have a MASSIVE beer hall with multiple levels, indoor, and outdoor seating. It is first come first serve and very busy. The beer is cold and delicious. For my main dish, I ordered the goulash and it was one of the best dishes I have had yet during my time in Germany. The service was okay as they are so busy. I would recommend ordering a large beer while you wait to order your food or to prepare to order everything ASAP to prevent spending too much time there. I came during the summer and it was very hot inside the beer hall, but outside was perfect.

We recently visited Germany and knew we had to come to the original location! Hofbrauhaus is uniquely German, with the band, the food, the tables and the beer! This location is the original, so it is very large. There are multiple rooms and multiple levels. They do take reservations, but it is not needed. You can just walk in and find a seat.There is a greeter/hostess, but she is just there to answer questions, you basically seat yourself. The seating is very long wooden tables. You can sit with other parties if your group is smaller, so definitely be prepared, someone else might sit with you.The menu is in German, but they had an English version as well. We were able to find a table right away but took almost 10 minutes for someone to come over. It gave us more time to look at the menu.I ended up ordering the ( 1/2 Bavarian roast chicken - with homemade potato salad) *this was utter one of best German meals I've ever had. The chicken was succulent and well seasoned. The homemade potato salad was delicious as well. It had a nice tang to it. For drinks, I ordered a liter of the Munchner Weisse (wheat beer). It was crisp, cold, and awesome.One of my friends order the same meal and she love it as well. My wife ordered the (Roast pork with crackling - fresh from the oven -served with homemade dark beer gravy and a potato dumpling)* My wife said she loved the pork immensely. The dumpling was just ok, it wasn't her favorite. Another friend ordered the Four pieces of pork sausage - served with mustard and sauerkraut. Our last friend ordered the spätzle with cheese and fried onions and the cream of potato and vegetable soup. These were also very good. All of the food was actually really delicious.The only thing I was not a fan of was the pretzel. They had girls walking around selling very large pretzels and they were hard and dry. Not what I expected. And they did not have the sweet mustard that we are used to getting at Hofbrauhaus in the US. They also had a polka style band that played music.The energy is very loud and upbeat. It is a fun time. This is best for groups but not required. Anyone can have a fantastic time here. Don't forget to check out the gift shop on your way out and make sure to buy something to remember your experience. I was definitely thrilled to come here, and this was one of the best meals the group had during our trip.

We have been to Hofbrauhaus many many times in the US. We recently visited Germany and knew we had to come to the original location! Hofbrauhaus is uniquely German, with the band, the food, the tables and the beer! This location is the original, so it is very large. There are multiple rooms and multiple levels. They do take reservations, but it is not needed. You can just walk in and find a seat. There is a greeter/hostess, but she is just there to answer questions, you basically seat yourself.  The seating is very long wooden tables. You can sit with other parties if your group is smaller, so definitely be prepared, someone else might sit with you. The menu is in German, but they had an English version as well. It is different than the locations in the US. I was expecting a menu I already knew but it was different. The only similar item was the pretzels, some sausages and the beer. We were able to find a table right away but took almost 10 minutes for someone to come over. She was extremely busy and had many many tables. My husband and I and another fried ordered the beer. The two guys got the liter size, and I chose the half liter size. Their beer is really delicious. I definitely enjoy it. For food, I ordered the crispy pork with crackling which was basically a giant crispy pork belly. It was served with gravy and a potato dumpling. The dumpling was just ok, not really my favorite, I should have ordered the spatzle instead, but the pork was delicious. Very good. MY husband and one of our friends ordered the 1/2 chicken which came with potato salad. It was very good as well, cooked really well and crispy on the outside. Another friend ordered the 4 different sausage plate which came with sauerkraut and then the last friend ordered the spätzle with cheese and fried onions and the cream of potato and vegetable soup. These were also very good. All of the food was actually really delicious. The only thing I was not a fan of was the pretzel. They had girls walking around selling very large pretzels and they were hard and dry. Not what I expected. And they did not have the sweet mustard that we are used to getting at Hofbrauhaus in the US. They also had a polka style band that played music. The energy is very loud and upbeat. It is a fun time. This is best for groups but not required. Anyone can have a fantastic time here. Don't forget to check out the gift shop on your way out and make sure to buy something to remember your experience. I was definitely thrilled to come here, and this was one of the best meals the group had during our trip.

This is a must visit place. The history itself is impressive. Their food is classic and beer is good. Please understand that this place gets extremely busy and crowded very fast so finding a table can be challenging at times. Your best bet is to walk around and if you find reserved tables, check the time of the reservation. If the reservation is within two or three hours, take it. Bring your patience, the waiters work hard to keep the food and drinks going. If the pretzel lady is walking around, know that she only accepts cash. Do get their big pretzel though, they are fresh out of the oven and delicious. Remember that they follow the beer purity law so the beer might be different from what you're accustomed to from whatever country you're from. Their dark beer is not as dark as a porter or stout but it is good nonetheless. We had an excellent dinner. Everything was hot and delicious. Our waiter was courteous and did an excellent job. Also know that if you're paying with card, you'll have to go with the waiter to pay for your food. They don't bring you a bill unless you're paying with cash. Also remember to ask if the service fee is included in the bill. That's basically the tip. However, from what I understand, most if not all restaurants pay a living wage so tips are not required but certainly appreciated if good service was received

I give the three stars primarily for what the restaurant stands for, not for our experience. Now this does need to be taken with a pinch of salt since we did visit during the busy season. However, our server was very short with us and clearly needing to go home for the day. We told her we were waiting for family to show up as we were ahead of them and she didn't think about what we told her and the table was split between two servers. That's not the biggest problem, our food didn't show up until those who came after us were almost done with their food! These were my first sausages of this trip and I must repeat this meal elsewhere because they were incredibly lackluster. It was nice to visit the location, experience this history, but this was surely a one and done for us.

Short review: Good food, Good Beer, quintessential German experience? NO. Too many tourists - granted I'm one of them.Full review: Do not come here if you're timid you'll never get a table. It's literally a madhouse, you have to hunt for your table then pounce on one as soon as the butt cheeks clear 2 inches from the chairs. The food is good especially the kasespaetzle, the caramelized cheese takes it up a notch. Also the  four pork sausage with sauerkraut, (thats not too sour) very earthy savory, not as sweet as the other sausages I've had here. We also liked the half roasted chicken. You can skip the pretzels and suckling pig.The Hofbrauhaus original beer goes down smooth with substance -  very good actually. And the same for the radler - just the right amount of sweetness with no aftertaste. Service despite the busyness of the place wasn't bad.

We were a party of five and ordered different dishes and all were on the salty side.(I guess you will drink more beer).  With one exception the wurst was not salty.  The beers were okay following the purity laws established in the 1500's but not my favorite from other breweries.Service was great had good server who interacted with us; an exception in Germany.We had a reservation and were seated on the second floor in the booth with the rendition of Mozart on the wall.The ambiance was great; reflecting on the history of this place and the ompah band playing live. In short come for the history and ambiance.

I would say this is a tourist trap. Very generic beer garden food. So if you are looking for something tasty, don't come here.Ok ish beer. Good salad. Ok ish pig knuckles and white sausages. Very rude service and very loud environment with difficult to carry out a good convo.I'm ok with coming here once to just get the experience but will not come back again.

It's a tourist trap.  You know it. They know it. Everyone knows it.  Walk in and you'll be guided to a table and sharing a large communal bench with groups from around the world.  My small group met some Australians and then two Brits living in the Cayman islands.  The hall was loud and the band played typical Bavarian music.  It's the closest you can come to Octoberfest when it's not Octoberfest.  The food is 30-50% more expensive than other places in the marienplatz.  The beer is also.  But that's what you pay for when you get here.  Just like anywhere in Germany, tipping is not required but here they will ask you for one because you're a foreigner.  As one of the Brits told me.  It might be a tourist trap, but when you're in Munich you have to spend one night at the hofbrauhaus.   I would definitely agree.  It's worth a visit!

It's the hofbrauhaus. A Munich icon. A must visit for any visitor to this great city. I have been there too many times to count and I have never been disappointed. The atmosphere is that of Oktoberfest with tons of beer HB of course and Bavarian feats and live music. Prices have increased over the past couple of years so expect to pay like any other restaurant in town. Service is not that great and I would normally deduct a start but can't do it for the HB!!

The food was decent and the beer was exactly what I hoped for. The place is crazy loud though. Not to sound like an old person complaining; I expected the Bavarian music and the place to be lively, but man it was so loud my Apple Watch kept warning me haha. If you're with a loud and boisterous party, you wouldn't even notice though.Service was more attentive than average, food was slow to arrive compared to beer, but I'm not complaining lol

Missed our connecting flight & had to stay overnight in Munich during Oktoberfest so we took an Uber so my husband & daughter could go to the oldest bar in Munich. It was very loud & crowded. The food was not that great & unfortunately we got a tired waiter. He said there was no salt nor soup. The beer was good. My previous visit a few years ago was better & it wasn't during Oktoberfest.

There is a musical ambiance appeal for sure. However, all else fails:: Service so terrible. Food so terrible. Like no joke. FOOD SO SO TERRIBLE. Not fresh. Pre-made. Heated in microwave or two seconds on a stove. Maybe. The beef cheeks. No good. The pork knuckle. So sad. The spätzle. So dry. The sausage. No taste. Just say no. Omg. Just do not come.
The ambiance was great but the quality of food was average. We had much better food in their branch in Berlin which is ironic since Munich is the original beer hall.

Service is fast!Extremely warm inside. Live music. Best to come when it is cold and rainy. Food tasted a bit salty. Live music is great. You first look for your own table, the. wave aserver and hope someone will come talk to you. We waiting over 10 + servers and finally someone comes! Price is cheap and food tasted fine! Cheaper than Christmas market or other restaurants. So many people inside.
A definite MUST stop if you're in Munich. The food was great, the history behind it all is fascinating.Just be prepared for long wait times on being serviced!

Came here once because I'd never been and the second time the very next day because it was that good. Highly recommend this place. Despite looking busy, find a spot at a table with others and take it all in. Food and atmosphere are top notch.

Okay for beer, but it's a bit like a Chuckee Cheese for tourists - meaning it's gimmicky as hell, overcrowded, sticky floors, loud and with a band playing every few minutes, and service is fast as lightning in that the staff is overextended. No clear vegan options. A pretzel man comes by with offerings available for cash euros. The spot dates back to the 16th century so the architecture is gorgeous though there are disturbing speciesist, classist, and violent murals adorning the walls that I wish would be updated to reflect new, modern Germany. It's Bavarian state government owned which I think is to blame for the history washing - turns out this place is the beer hall of the Hitler beer hall speech. It would be really great if this was made clear to guests in a way that was respectful to the victims of the Nazi party and honored them rather than hiding this to maintain a joyful atmosphere. We felt pretty gross when we found out and wished there had been a spot carved out to pay respects to those murdered and acknowledge the atrocities. And perhaps some of the earnings can be donated to concentration camp survivors and families, or museums that maintain their stories and legacies. Context: Adolf Hitler announced the official program of the Nazi Party to a meeting of around 2,000 people at the Hofbräuhaus on 24 February 1920. At the time, he was propaganda chief of the party whilst the organisation was still relatively small. On 29 July 1921, he was elected Führer of the Nazi Party during a meeting at the Hofbräuhaus am Platzl.

No visit to Munich is complete without an experience at the Hofbrauhaus! We came here for lunch on a Thursday and it was nearly at capacity, and this restaurant is huge!You seat yourself at a shared picnic table; be careful not to sit in reserved spots. The live Oompah band was in full swing, but nearly drowned out by the massive chatter from the many patrons.They have several beers to choose from and, of course, you have to get the 1 Litre stein! I wanted the Munich, veal sausages, but they were out of them, so I went with the grilled sausages and sauerkraut. Very average food, but hey, it's an iconic place and worthy of the unique experience.
Fun spot for a beer. We also got a GIANT pretzel but missed the photo.  Super cool and very busy. The food menu looks good but unfortunately we had already eaten.

I can only review the service because we left without receiving food. I made a reservation for my party of 4, weeks in advance. We were seated promptly but that's where the service ended. We waited almost an hour without receiving menus or anyone taking our drink or food order. Any attempt to wave down a server were ignored. I got up twice to ask the hostess and the server for help and they kept telling me that they are busy and they will take my order soon. When we finally left an hour after being seated with no service, the hostess was rude and unapologetic. I am so disappointed, as I was looking forward to this experience for weeks as a highlight of my trip to Germany.
Beer- good, Food-lame, service- lammer, setting meh............and that's all I have to say about that.....

It was nice to get a chance to visit during our stay.While planning our stay in Munich, I was reading the website which talked about making reservations, but there was no availability the whole time we were going to be in Munich so we did not plan on even trying. The good news is we did make it while on a small private city tour, walked right in. This was late afternoon. There is nothing better that a cold beer, well maybe two. The food was also good. This was my third pork shank of the trip. English menus and waiter made this stop easy. Great service.

Yes, it's touristy but when in Munich, you owe it to yourself to visit the Hofbrauhaus at least once.  The atmosphere is festive and wide eyed tourists sit alongside merry local gentlemen sipping their mugs of beer! The oompah band, singing and jovial laughter added to the fun. The food was suprisingly decent.  My husband had beer and wurst (of course) and I had a glass of Gruner Veltliner wine and a green salad which was better than expected. The fresh pretzel was delicious! Last of all, the Hofbrauhaus has an extensive souvenir shop with signature blue and white items at all different price points.  The rubber ducks dressed in lederhosen and hats were adorable and cost just 4 euros!
Great stop, its always Oktoberfest here! Band, tables, beer! I was told it is usually crowded and often has a wait.

If you visit Munich, this is a MUST (touristy) stop for a Beer stein and food at the Hofbrau Haus!  A world renowned place is busy ALL the time, and generally 1st come seating; and in German style, you may be sharing part of your table with others depending how many friends you bring! But everyone is friendly, the mood is festive and the brews and eats are excellent. So even if you come on your own, you'll make lots of new friends at a table!  Be patient, service timing is efficient but not fastest, but allows you time to soak in the experience!  Overall, a 4.5+ rating for me based on ambience, fun crowd, good beers, friendly service and authentic food, especially the Pork options, yum!  Expect to pay $15-18euro for a meal plate, but the quantity is shareable for 2 if modest appetites.  Of course, apps, famous pretzels, and more are available, so you won't go hungry or thirsty!Tried the special cheese dip spread for starter; chilled and mildly tasty went well on bread or a pretzel.  Plenty to share and compliments the beer for sure!  The homemade Potato soup is also flavorful and creamy.Ordered 3 dinner types. My personal fave was the Roast Pork with Crackling;  tender sliced and slow roasted pork had a crispy topping, served with homemade beer gravy and potato dumpling - delicious comfort fare!  Also tried the Suckling Pig shank which was super tender, tasted like traditional Ham; served with parsley potatoes atop sauerkraut and side horseradish.  Finally, the whole roasted Knuckle of Pork was their signature item; wonderful and filling, but you had to manage eating meat off the bone, thus I liked first choice best. You won't go wrong with any food selection here, just bring your appetites!Beer (dark, light) steins by the liter (33oz) are typical, but you can get 1/2L and yes they offer limited wine alternatives for non-brew fans.This landmark spot was worth the visit, check it out in Munich, PROST!  Enjoy!!!

My Dad was stationed in Germany in the 60's, before I was born, I am 58.My wife and I went to Munich for Oktoberfest this year for the first time.  My Dad said I had to go here, as it one of the places he most remembered from Munich and Oktoberfest.  It did not disappoint.It was exactly as he described it from the 60's with the great food, great beer, and Polka Bands!!!The more things change the more they stay the same!!!

Wanted to visited a beer house and that we did! Beer was pretty good, as someone who does not have much beer. Food wise, we tried the beef tartare. I can't say much other than I don't think I personally like it, so whether it's good or not I cannot say. Service was very busy, you have to find a seat yourself amongst the bustling restaurant, but it wasn't very slow once you managed to do so. The ambiance is amazing, I would say it's worth coming just to experience the live music and unique atmosphere.

Cash only. It's very loud and the service is rushed and rude. Compared to other beer gardens we have been to, this one was the least enjoyable. No need to visit this one if you have limited time in Munich. We decided to stop by after learning a bit about the history from one of our tour guides and wanted to see the hanging angel. However it was quite disappointing. We sat ourselves and waited for awhile before a waiter rushed by and demanded "0.5l, 1l"?? While taking orders from our table and another one at the same time. A few minutes later a few steins were slammed onto our table with the price and "cash only" hollered at us. Ambience is extra loud. You will not be able to hear anyone talking.

Having been to Germany before, specifically to Hofbrau in Munich, I had to return.  For those that don't know what the experience is like in a German Beer Hall, it's amazing but daunting at first.  You share tables with anyone that fits at it. Typically four or five people to a side. So don't get weirded out that a group of people you don't know sat with you or the only place to sit is with people you don't know, that is all part of the experience.  Hofbrau is a busy place. Like super busy. You will find seating, but you have to be ready for the motion and energy in there.  There is constant movement, great music, toasting, and a good high energy.  The food is classic Bavarian fare. Europe doesn't over sugar everything like we do in America, but it makes it taste better because you can't mask flavors with sugar.  We want during Oktoberfest, so there was a lot of the same items across the board, probably for ease of making large quantities.  All in, the food and beer in Munich is world class. Ok, on to the food.  We had pork knuckle, German meatloaf, and Spätzle. The pork knuckle was amazing. It comes out on two bones so you have to work at it to get the meat off, but each bite was worth it. The potato dumpling that came with it was an unexpected consistency. It was really good, just didn't expect it to have an actual dumpling consistency. The meatloaf was good, but man did it get amazing when I put the mustard on it that came with it.  It looked like bologna, but it was just a really flavorful meatloaf.  The breading or crust on the outside of it added to the flavor and experience as a whole.  Spätzle was new to us, but it was love at first bite.  It's like a Mac and cheese, but the "noodles" are more like a dough so they taste fantastic with whatever is put on them.  We had multiple versions on our trip and were never disappointed. If you're in Munich, it's in your best interest to hit up Marienplatz for the Glockenspiel, then mosey around the corner to this amazing brew house. Hofbrau never disappoints.

Cool beer hall but good luck finding a seat during dinner time, almost a seat yourself if you can find a seat in this giant maze of tables and rooms. Our waiter was rather pushy as we didn't know what we wanted to order after finding a seat. He also kept repeating a tip option while we were paying. The food was ok, very hot plates with room temperature food. Also watch where you're walking, the waiters/waitresses will nearly knock you out with their trays

I decided not to eat here last time I was in Germany with my mother but this time I was here with my fiancee on a business trip with him, so we joined several of his co-workers for dinner here one night. The inside is beautiful and they are almost always crowded.  It has about three levels which I didn't realize before, so we ended up eating upstairs and there was plenty of seating. The menu is loaded with typical Bavarian dishes. So think meat, potatoes, pretzels, more meat, and carbs, carbs, carbs.  LOL. I don't drink alcohol so I didn't try that - but we did order a starter for the table of some typical items which consisted of pretzels, bread, meat, cheese, and some mixture of cheese and butter and eggs like a spread that was absolutely delicious (and I'm sure not healthy at all but hey, it's vacation).  I chose the beef goulash served with a side of spaetzle and it was not good.  My fiancee had ordered goulash while we were in Salzburg for my birthday a few days prior and it was delicious and flavorful but this was nothing like that.  Tasted like it came out of a can and the spaetzle was rubbery and flavorless.  My fiancee ordered pork knuckle and I tasted it, it was pretty decent but super fatty and I was just pretty much grossed out overall by the dishes. Fortunately, I ordered a side salad that was pretty good and it was my savior for the meal. I ordered the apple strudel as well and didn't enjoy it.  It was just not high quality. We had a good time and service was very good and, at the end, a huge party of locals came upstairs and started playing their own instruments to rival the rivalry that happens on the first floor, so that was pretty cool. We stayed 9 days in Munich so I was pretty familiar with the city and local area by the time we left having walked around for days and dined all over the place for three different meals a day. It's an experience to enjoy a meal and a few beers in this historic building established by the kings of Bavaria that dates back hundreds and hundreds of years.  I googled the hofbrauhaus after we ate here and was impressed with everything I discovered, so it's worth a visit, but the food was not at all as good as you can find in the rest of Munich.  I'd recommend you come for a drink, enjoy the music, and dine somewhere else!

The same aspects that make this a staple of Munich and a must-see for any one visiting also leave me giving only 3 stars. We are glad we went and experienced this famous beer hall but have no reason to visit again. The younger me might have completely loved the atmosphere 10+ years ago but in our old age, we learned that finding a small, local beer hall to explore was more our speed. The Hofbrauhaus is massive, loud, crowded, and full of beer. The tables are shared by multiple parties, people are cramped in, and trying to walk through the aisles to tables is an adventure. The servers are constantly scrambling and carrying handfuls of mugs - they are also not the friendliest or helpful for this reason. You should viisit and experience this place, but for us, once was enough.

I mean, you have to go here. Its big. It's crowded. Its wonderful. Get a liter and hang a while. It's touristy, but this is why you came. Service is steady, so be patient. Food comes quickly once you order, and the beer never stops.

Probably the most famous dining/party establishment in Germany! This is the original home of the smiling ladies with their arms full of beer steins. The restaurant is HUGE. Indoor space, outdoor space, multiple levels, multiple rooms. One COULD get lost, if they aren't paying attention!Delicious food and THE home of Hofbrauhaus beer, have you really seen Munich if you haven't been here? I'd say no, but I say a lot of things when I'm drunk, so..... The gift shop is outstanding, with all kinds of fun stuff for sale. It's a great place to pick up some head gear for Oktoberfest.Another must-see in Munich if, for nothing else, to at least say, "Yeah, I've been there!"7/2022

You need to go to this place for the experience!  First you come in and you kinda seat yourself.  You look for an open spot and grab it.  Then your server comes and will give you the menu to look over and will come back for your order.  You have to order the large beer because that's what they are known for.  While your are waiting for your beer a gal comes around and sells bread and pretzels from her basket.  The pretzels are legit and cost about 5euros.  They only take cash.  The restaurant itself takes credit card.   The food is decent pricing and our group tried a lot of dishes on the menu. Downside is that it's pretty salty but I figure it's because they want you to drink more beer lol.The ambiance is definitely why you go there. The band in the front plays ofter and makes it super loud and fun.  Will I go back?  If I have new guests going with me to Germany then I would definitely take them here.
Lively atmosphere! Be prepared to wait an extended time for service, however a must visit while in Munich! Food was good, and the beer was flowing!

A Munich institution. It's always busy, so you may have trouble finding a seat. Tasty food and great beer.  The live music is fun but can be LOUD. We come here every time we're in Munich.Supposedly the 1st floor has quieter options with large tables but it was closed when last we went.

Tourists from all over the world converge on this madhouse - but the music is always good and the atmosphere is always weird.  Screaming, angry waitresses from Bosnia scold you for sitting down at their tables while drunk tourists spill beer all over your 1000 dollar lederhosen- it's cool though otherwise why go at all?  We used to run Stammtisch parties here so it can' be all bad...I don't know how to explain this place: it sucks and is fun at the same time but you have to have 4 Augustiners somewhere else to get through the culture shock upon arrival

You come here for the histort, ambiance, and the beer!!!The good was good but not great.  The large pretzel was fresh and soft.  Great with some mustard.I had the wienerschnitzel with a knudel as a side.  Overall, it was average.  Friend had the sausages and they were good.You have to go here at least once in your life.

Lively, energetic experience at the Hofbrauhaus and luckily visited during a time that was not very busy (off peak lunch time). Servers were still extremely busy, and hats off to them for how they carry all the beer in the 1L mugs. Food was flavorful, though perhaps not plentiful in portion. Menu was in English and even had allergen notices. Well organized. Many different areas to sit throughout the restaurant.Would recommend.
Always a must when you come to Munich! Be prepared to hunt for a table. They now make you pay right away when you order. Band needs to stop taking so many breaks.

This is the original Hofbrauhaus. A pilgrimage for the man. Having been to the copies in Las Vegas and Kentucky, this one is the best. The food was awesome compared to the copies. The man had the schweinshaxe and I enjoyed the Kasespatzle.

Food was good.  Beer and atmosphere were great.  Very busy place.  We were kind of snatched up by a waiter as soon as we walked in the door so really didn't get to explore or check out the beer garden.  Gift shop is very small.

Amazing place and a must see in Munich! We stopped by, got some huge beers and a big pretzel. It's also got live music and people dancing around. Humongous building and the food looked great but we showed up only 2 min after 10pm and the kitchen was closed and the wait staff was completely inflexible. It was such a shame, so we ended up getting McDonald's instead. Otherwise a great time

Worth visiting as a tourist to see an authentic beer garden. Our food was yummy - soup was very flavorful, the sausage was so-so. We also ordered a bread basket (not pictured) that was delicious! Of course you have to get a beer while you're here :) Try to beat the huge tourist crowds & go just before normal lunch time, or wait it out and go a little after. Live music, crowded but not annoyingly so, and our server was fine. Not rude just not overly chatty haha. Cool place!
Good for a tourist experience but do not expect good customer service - or food for that matter. In fact, prepare to be treated as a nuisance. Eat before you go.
Traditional German beer hall culture and food, a lots of meat, open market environment, a lots people usually, is a must to visit in my view for visitors. Casual and easy.

This is a must-see if you're visiting Munich.Having only been to their two locations in Ohio, I had to stop by. The scene is slightly chaotic but the energy is magnetic.My friend and I were afraid we wouldn't get a seat because it was tremendously crowded but fortunately we found a table right away. Our very attentive server came and took our drink orders right away. We tried both the light and dark Radlers featured on the menu. They come in one size: HUGE! They were delicious drinks but the atmosphere is what made the experience. The live oompa music and the staff in their Bavarian attire created that German atmosphere that we were seeking.I would also like to point out that they have a very nice gift shop and I was pleasantly surprised by the reasonable prices.Definitely check this place out!

Germany indeed has the best beer and this tavern serves it. The most memorable thing i ate is their Kasespatzle. (Photo attached) creamy, savory goodness! Their specialty is also their sausages and pork knuckles. They were ok. Maybe i had high expectations. :) The servers were nice and there were ladies dressed in oktoberfest fraulein outfits offering pretzels. There was music and clapping. Overall it was a fun experience. The place was packed but we were able to get a table right away.
Just horrible bad service waited thirty minutes for service the waiters are rude then we left because we gave up.10 out of 10 would not recommend ,got this app just for this review.
Lots of fun, great food and beer. I went here during Oktoberfest and it was an experience. My waiter was super nice so we were fortunate.

This is the brewhouse you must absolutely check out on a trip to Munich! It's big, it's historical, the beer/food is delicious, and Adolf Hitler announced the official program of the Nazi Party to a meeting of around 2,000 people at the Hofbräuhaus on 24 February 1920. The last part is from Wikipedia and everyone usually mentions Hitler when talking about this joint.I enjoyed this place so much I bought the 425 Year Anniversary Hofbräuhaus Beer Stein for like $300. My dreams pretty much came true checking this place out so I thought it was justified.I get it--it's touristy, can be pricey, and there are probably better places if you're just looking to grab a beer and food without the craziness. However, my recommendation to you is that you come here for the energy, Germany band, cheers, and amazingness that is the historical Hofbräuhaus!

Came here to experience the original Hofbrauhaus.  Was pretty tempered down because of covid, and can only imagine how loud and viby it may be during normal times. Beer was deliciousFood was average - would not come here specially for the food

How to even begin describing HB?? This place is huge and wild and fun and unforgettable! We visit each time we're in Munich sometimes multiple times a trip because the atmosphere cannot be replicated. They are checking vaccine status and require masks when walking around. Once you're given the OK you walk around to find a table. Completely seat yourself and you often times have to sit at tables with other parties because the tables are large and can accommodate multiple groups. Definitely not the time to be shy! Step up and get in there or you won't find a table. The servers are very busy and don't come around super often. Try to have your order ready as soon as possible. They have menus in MANY different languages, so don't hesitate to ask if you're having difficulty. The menu is definitely smaller with fewer offerings than was was offered pre-Covid. For instance I was in LOVE with the roast fest chicken and unfortunately that is no longer on the menu. We ordered the Nuremberg sausages with sauerkraut and the potato soup. The soup was absolutely delicious! Creamy and warm. Perfect for a winters night. We also ordered several liters of beer and that beer is truly the best. You can order the weisse beer in a liter even though the menu does not list it out. They accept cash and card, but you have to walk with your server to the pay station if you want to pay with card. They often have live music on a little stage. Very traditional German fest music which makes the space even more lively and entertaining! Hofbräuhaus is a must visit during your stay in Munich! It's touristy, but it truly is a one of a kind experience!

Must try Munich experience, get the grilled pork knuckle and the white sausage. They have excellent pretzels to accompany the big portion of  meat.  Find an open seat that is not reserved and they will take your order.  Very lively and touristy. What a great experience.

You have to go while in Munich, despite how touristy it can be (it's touristy for a reason, right?). Beer is fantastic and so is the food. The service is hit or miss. I came in at 11am when they opened and my wife and I seated at one of the tables. One of the ladies assuming a waitress scolded at us for sitting at a big table and should sit at the small ones. Looking around, all the tables are the same size and saw some people with 2-3 sitting at the same ones we sat at. I was nearly annoyed and felt like we were not welcomed. My wife was ready to just leave and annoyed I asked a waiter what is their definition of a small table because we were told we were not welcomed to sit at the longer ones. He gestured to sit at his area and it's ok to sit at the big table. Obviously he was way more friendly and attentive. He took our orders and served our drinks and food rather quickly. Because of his willingness, I left a nice tip for him. Overall, a positive experience despite the first encounter with the waitress. Would I come back? Perhaps, but there are other places to try too. Now that I've been here, I can go check out other brew houses since there are so many.

TIP: they do not seat you, find your own table. The tables with the paper tents on them are reserved! Definitely a tourist destination, it was fun, loud and full of energy. If we hadn't done the Third Reich Tour I'm not sure we would have come here (Hitler would give speeches here and up until the early 2000's the SS was still on the ceilings). We ordered the Spaetzle (no photo) pork sausage and sauerkraut and of course beer (light and dark). All were fine. There were vendors walking around selling giant pretzels and chocolate cookies (paid separately and cash only). The atmosphere is what makes this place great, our server, Mohammed (sp?) was a blast!
A fun experience. Good beer, good service, reasonable prices. The band makes for a lively atmosphere.Go find yourself a seat. Folks are friendly and will make room for you.

The menu is very limited and seasonal, the ambiance extremely loud and chaotic. We didn't get to try the food as it was super crowded. Seems like this is a great place to enjoy beer as they have a huge variety.

You know it's going to be touristy, but honestly I really enjoyed it here. Very boisterous, loud, beer hall with awesome food. We headed here right after our flight and it was an excellent first meal. Also really great for people watching and soaking in the city.

Place is amazing.  A definite stop for any tourist in Munich.  One of if not the largest bier garden in Munich.  Place was packed and to be fair I didn't order food so I can't comment on that.  The beer was very good and atmosphere with band playing was electric.  Don't expect good service as this place is mobbed and staff just simply get overrun by the crowds.  But if you are looking for a nice Bavarian beer hall experience with music and atmosphere this is the place to stop.

People have called this a tourist trap, but I only think that term applies to places that get unjustified hype. In our opinion, this place deserves the hype. There's a beer for everyone. I personally don't like the after taste of most beers, so I went with the radler, which is mixed with lemonade. It was so good! I got the pork knuckle because it's the specialty of the area, and it didn't disappoint. Tender and flavorful. Definitely recommend trying it! The vibes were just so fun, and it really made for the best last day in Munich for us. Open seating and shared seating, meaning you find open seats and sit at a table with strangers. I usually wouldn't be a fan of this, but when traveling it makes it fun because it feels like you have to talk to the people at your table. So we got to meet new people and ask them about their beer and food choices. There was a live band when we were there, which just brought it all together. 10/10 we will definitely come back if we ever find ourselves back in Munich!

This is definitely a must stop while in Munich! The atmosphere is loud and fun! Get ready to grab any seats available with your group or share with another group. The music is festive and definitely has a Bavarian Beer Garden vibe. Stick with the traditional menu items and they won't disappoint.
Great experience!! Great tourist spot !! Be prepared to wait for a table once seated service moved pretty fast. Food was great had  the pork shank. Family style dining.

I wouldn't have cared to visit this "tourist trap", but my s.o. insisted, so now I'm sitting in a loud hall with the temperature and humidity of a sauna.The food is decent, though not really worth a detour.The waiter insisted that we pay as soon, as our food was delivered, apparently this is the only way to manage the chaos in this big and noisy place. Food and drink delivery was pretty fast though, so no complaints there.All in all this isn't a place I'd care to visit again.
Such a fun atmosphere! A must visit on your trip. The band was entertaining and lively and the people were so friendly and fun.
Food was good, service ok and lots of beer. Classic German bier Hall. It was a bit warm the early evening we were there but lots of activity.
Simply the best. I had 15 hrs layover in Munich and decided to experience beer culture in Germany. Awesome atmosphere; best food and of course the beer !!!
The food is just OK, but if you go to Munich, you have to have a beer and experience the Hofbrauhaus!

Worth it. Built in 1589, Hofbräuhaus is one of the oldest taverns in the heart of Munich. Believe it or not, Adolf hitler even gave a speech founding the national socialists party. Try the Hofbrau original beer. A Radler is a good as well if you're not a beer fan. We ordered the white sausage as a side, The mustard that's served with the sausage was prime. 4 stars due to the service being awfully slow. It took us nearly minutes to get served and another 30 to get our sausage. They made up for it by being super friendly. I recommend buying of one the huge 1 liter glasses to take a home as a souvenir at the gift

An awesome beer hall that gets really crowded and loud but the food and drink more than make up for it. If you can (or are willing to try) speak German with your waiters and you will get better service I think. Don't be a jerk - that's how you get poor service. The Schweinshaxe is the best item here although the roast chicken is also very good. Love their dumplings. The Dunkle beer is my favorite but the Weiße is quite nice too. Pretzels were a bit dry and you have to ask for mustard - they don't just bring it with the pretzel. The desserts are just ok but you don't really expect Apfelstrudel to be amazing at a beer hall right?My youngest kid got a little toy pack with anime stickers at the end from the waiter because it was Christmas - so sweet of them!Highly recommend
Seasonal beer is tasty and the food delicious. Shoutout to the musicians that keep the ambiance totally Bavarian!!! Server was efficient. Try it all!!

Been here many times-never ate more than the pretzel (omg).  Beer, beer, beer-that's what this is all about. Bavarian brass band playing live, a pretzel (even if the Germans font understand putting mustard on it) and a mug in the bier garten is truly a joy.

You can't be a tourist in Munich without visiting the famous Hofbräuhaus. If you're in the Marianplatz area the beer house is approximately a 5-10 minute walk depending on your physique.  The two of us visited Hofbräuhaus on the whim in the evening with no reservations. This place is loud with music, laughter, and chatter. Our waiter gave us more than enough time to figure out what we wanted to drink and eat. He also gave us the run down on what's what on the menu since he originally handed us a German menu. The food arrived quick and piping hot. The portions are quite big so with a few pints of beer and a platter full of meat (I had their grilled sausages platter and schnitzel platter) and you're destined to go home full, bloated, and sleepy. If you're in Munich you have to visit this place just for the fun atmosphere.

The place is wildly packed. But for good reason. The inside looks great and really transports you. I really felt like I was chilling in game of thrones eating huge slabs of meat and drinking beer taller than my head. It was a great experience and a very memorable location. It's very hard to get a good table. Plant to possibly wait a bit. I didn't get to sit in the main hall but we were able yo walk through it. There are other slightly more cozy areas to sit if that's what you want. I enjoyed the food. Next time I go I would try a lighter beer, as I do tend to prefer those.
Genuinely awful. If you want a beer hall experience and are willing to overlook bad food and bad service, by all means, go ahead, but don't expect much.

beautiful part of munich but don't expect much from the staff. you will get "don't bother me with that" if you want mustard with the pretzel. the pretzel lady will tell you to get from waiter and the waiter will tell you, basically, to go fuck yourself. the food that we did manage to get was super, but they apparently don't have a very good way to get the food to you, or at least have a distinctly hostile attitude. i can't fault the hostility of the waiter/waitress too much because they are super overcrowded, so good luck getting that second, very overpriced beer...

If you're visiting Munich/Munchen, go here! A trip is not complete without going here. The food is good, the music is live & the staff is quick. Schnitzel! I love schnitzel! I tried Schnitzel in Switzerland and it is way better here by a million miles. Vienna sausage! Real Vienna sausage! The casing is so crisp and the sausages are super smooth and flavorful. Visit, you won't regret it!

Tourist trap where the service was just horrible.  There was no air conditioning so it was not comfortable. The food was ah; and bier is bier, but their bier had nothing but maybe a history to it.  I would not go back or recommend even if invited and paid for me...

So if you're looking for a place to drink this is it! If you're looking for a quiet meal with friendly service keep going.This place is an icon! This lively tavern has been copied it in Las Vegas and other major cities. I've been to the one in Vegas, in Munich you just sit wherever, with who ever. It was different.You've got to flag down a server for beer or food like you've been stranded and have a medical emergency.The food was good, as expected, nice to have an English menu. Nothing was bad to include the beer. Only stars removed for service, as it was early (1745) on a Friday night,Sadly, this is also where Hitler announce to a few thousand people that he was forming a party back in 1920....so I guess you could say it is good for parties. Someone from the restaurant might want to have that fact removed from Wikipedia.

This beautiful pub situated in the heart of Munich was so much fun! The band was poppin' & the food was excellent & the beer was flowing! The people; from the band members to the servers to the clientele were all so much fun! What a party!

I had an amazing experience here. I dont even like beer. I ended up throwing up in the bathroom and going back to drinking. My friend jumped in with the polka band. They let him play one of their horns. It was epic.

This noisy, boisterous fun venue captured the essence of the German beer hall.  Beer was great (huge stein!) and the sausages with sauerkraut and mustard hit the spot.  Be advised...the servers don't come up to you to take your order! A good 30 min almost if trying to flag a server down appears par for the course.  But it's all part of the experience!

After seeing all the reviews and recommendations on every travel site, we decided that it was a must stop while in Munich. We sat ourselves on the upper level patio and the staff provided English menus to us. We ordered some Radlers, munich sausages, the pork knuckle and roast pork crackle. Don't order pretzels on the menu. Instead, wait for the vendors to walk around and sell them. They are huge and 5€ each. Plan on bringing cash for that! The food was so good that we went twice during our stay. Our 2nd time around, seating was very limited but people are constantly going in and out so be patient and don't be afraid to sit at a table that hasn't been cleared yet. They accept cash or card. If I ever end up in Munich again, I will definitely be back.

What a terrible experience. The food was adequate, but the service made the experience unpleasant. It was bad enough that the waiters were yelling at each other, but then our waiter was exceptionally rude with us. He actually yelled and swore when we wanted to split the bill. A waitress told him that it would be easy to do, but he continued to berate us until a manager finally intervened and allowed us to pay. It was a very upsetting experience. I would not recommend this restaurant to anyone as long as they treat customers so disrespectfully.

The manager or the person in charge stated to our groupThat u were a half hour late I am sold out anyway " get out and I don't care" I can't help u", I am a retired police officer in the US and I an assure u I am a good witness , the majority of our group are seniors , the overall conduct of your senior staff was deplorable and very disappointing , I hope u speak to your staff because your actions tonight was very upsetting

Great experience.  You do get close to people in the general area, but this is very much a part of the appeal.  We had a wonderful and delicious dinner.   Certainly worth doing in Munich, and a great experience!
Every time I visit Munich, I have to get several beers from here. The food is okay, the staff is friendly. We enjoy the live music and the overall experience.

We had reservations for 6pm and that process was quiet annoying unfortunately. You walk in a big hall and there is no one there to greet you and there is no direction of what needs to be done. After talking to about 10 people and going all over the restaurant after 15-20 mins we finally got somewhere (yes, our group speaks German as well so there is no misunderstanding). After we got thru that whole fiasco and finally got seated everything was good. Our waiter Vicric was wonderful and personable. They spoke both German and English for our group for people who did not understand German. We had a great time and the food was ok. Seeing it a big tourist spot you can always find better at a mom and pop place but it still was not bad. Of course the beer is great and reasonably priced. All the history with the place it was a great experience and something I think everyone in the area should enjoy atleast once to say they have.

Food was good and the beer was better! The music transported us back to the ultimate Bavarian beer hall. It was always a party atmosphere. Way to warm to really enjoy ourselves but we had a good time anyway.

I guess this is a must visit place when visiting Munich, at least once for the experience. Hofbräuhaus is a very large beer house which is quite busy, loud, lots of activity, and it can be fun. There is a band that plays Bavarian music but not continuously as they take short breaks between each set. But when they do play, it gets the crowd excited and on their feet. The beer is good and the food is your typical German/Bavarian stuff, and the prices are average. This place is an institution and draws locals and lots of tourists. Check it out and you can say you've visited one of the largest and famous beer houses in Munich.

I mean I wasn't going to come to München for 24 hours and NOT see the Hofbrauhaus?! Is it touristy - a bit, but I saw plenty of German people there too enjoying beer and food. The beer was good, what I would expect. I enjoyed a nice Liter of Oktoberfest Bier, and then a lovely lady came around selling pretzels and I was in heaven. You guys don't understand how much I love a German Pretzel. They are massive too! I obviously couldn't leave without having a Dunkel, though as I was a bit delirious from the travel over from Denver I thought it wise to get the smaller one. I didn't get any food because I had another spot I wanted to check out, but it all looked pretty dang good.Service is a bit slow, you just kind of have to make eye contact and get your order in, but that's because there are only a few people taking care of the whole area, and let me tell you the staff is hustling, they have got to be burning 10000 cals in a shift so cut them some slack! I thought they were very nice and it was fine by me!
Really great atmosphere and food and they had music to welcome us when we arrived and lots of tables and chairs and no booking required
Amazing experience atmosphere Beer and food with live music. Definitely a must if you are in Munich

I think if you're looking for the authentic beer house experience this is a can't miss. Seating it first come first find. So if you're going with a large group go on weekdays or off peak hours.  Prices are reasonable and the food is very good. Beer quality goes without saying.  Wait staff was nice but very busy when we were there.
It's aight. It's Budweiser in Germany. If you want a real German experience I recommend augustiner
Great place to enjoy German beer and food.  Just head in and find an open spot and make some new friends.  Good live music as well.
The Bavarian Experience - complete with delicious food, appropriately rowdy guests, an entertaining brass band, and wonderful service. 10/10 recommend. All are welcome.

The worst service I've ever had. Rude and entitled. Couldn't manage to get a pretzel to us at the same time- lol a pretzel - made an excuse. Recommend- skip it and go to the Augustiner across the street.l- so much better.

A must try if in Munich.  Traditional setting and food.  Loved the experience but the food was just not my thing.  The pork knuckle was good but nothing great.  The locals were loving it though.    Service was good.

I had been to the Las Vegas Hofbräuhaus before but I certainly had long wanted to visit the original.  This is certainly a fantastic and historic structure and both the inside and outside beer hall and beer gardens were everything I would have dreamed they could be.  I also had the added bonus of being able to visit during Oktoberfest which just added to the joyful ambiance of the space.  The food and beer were all some of the best I had during my time in Germany.Pro-Tip: If you get exhausted looking for a seat at the Oktoberfest tents you can just go to one of the breweries for a similar experience with much easier to find seats.

This place is definitely an experience! I can't speak about the food because my husband and I only drank our meal here, but the atmosphere and service and entertainment were pretty great.   We came on the evening of the 25th of december and I remember reading reviews that it is always a mad house with about a 2hr wait.... Which is insane because this place is 3 gigantic floors of tables & chairs. But on the 25th, it was not a mad house. It was packed, but there was still plenty of room for us to sit and grab a giant beer. There was a live band playing when we walked in and they were great! Traditional German beer hall music. It was like we walked into a movie. There was this one really drunk, really big customer trying to be the maestro for the band, it was pretty hilarious.  A few days later my husband & I decided to go back for another beer before dinner out, but this time it was the aforementioned mad house. Every floor was filled to the brim, there were tons of people waiting for tables. We did not stay. I'm just glad we went on the 25th!  I will try to go again the next time I'm in Munich. Lots of fun!

Hofbräuhaus is widely known as the world's most famous beer hall. When in Munich, it's a definite must-visit.
