While they now have locations around the world, Munich is the original where it all began in the year 1589. This beer hall is not just world famous, but very historic.My friends and I stopped in here on a Friday night around 6pm without reservations. We were very lucky to find a group that was leaving, so we quickly grabbed their table. If you can, try to make reservations, because this is one of the most popular places to drink in town, especially during Oktoberfest.Unfortunately, I didn't take too many pictures here, but my friends and I enjoyed a mass (~34 oz.) of beer each and I ordered spaetzle for dinner. The food was good and the beer paired well. The atmosphere is definitely fun and lively. Service was decently quick considering the chaos. Though Hofbrauhaus was not my favorite beer hall that we visited in Munich, it is definitely worth checking out.

This was everything I wanted it to be and more. After finding out our included dinner at our hotel would be chicken and rice, my cousin suggested going out to dinner. I conceded the hotel dinner if we could eat here. I'm so glad we did!First off, there are 2 dining areas. There is a more formal, relaxed area on the 2nd floor. Then there is the beer hall area - which is where we were headed. You basically have to stalk the room for a place to sit and then you are going to be sitting with strangers (unless you have 6-8 people). It is complete chaos and craziness and I loved every minute. After getting our server's attention, we ordered beer and food. I opted for the Radler liter and roast beef. The beer was delicious and the food was amazing. I loved the sauce on the roast beef. There is a band that plays and a toasting song that the locals sing along with. There is also a souvenir shop to visit as well. We sat with some guys from Slovenia who will give me stories to tell for ages. Definitely come by here if you are in Munich!

One of the busiest restaurants I've ever seen. Complete chaos. No real rules on where to sit or how to order. Truly a free-for-all.Whether I knew this beforehand or not didn't really keep me from coming here, as I was told while in Munich this place was not to be missed. I could see why, but also if you have any kind of social anxiety or get claustrophobic in a crowd I highly recommend not coming here.I finagled my way into a table shared with many others. A nice non-English speaking German gentleman assisted me in getting a very large...nay, gigantic vat of beer. Apparently there is only one size. As I two-handedly drank my liter of beer, I patiently awaited my food (schnitzel, a crowd favorite and house specialty) and listened to the traditional music played by a band of men donning lederhosen. What a sight! Although my food took nearly an hour (and wasn't that warm or good) and the place was packed full of all of Munich, I'm glad I went. With a unique ambience and the kindness of locals I'll always have a story to tell about the city.

Come for the beers, music and festive feelings; have low expectations on the food and service. We ordered the roast pork (Krustenschweinebraten) which was more moist and not as dry as the pork knuckles (Schweinehaxe). Both a little salty with a dry crispy skin that's hard to eat. Same applied to the liver soup (Rinderbrühe) as it was really salty.Service was slow and know what you want to order as servers are not very patient. Noticed that we didn't even get bread that a group of five got next to us. Because it is not customary to tip, servers aren't motivated to work for tips.Music, dancing and entertainment was the best part of the experience! Come with some family and friends and enjoy the festive feeling. Tip: Go to the Christmas Market nearby for some bratwurst and glühwein!

Came here only because it's the oldest beer house in Munich and basically a tourist must-do. We accidentally went up to the 2nd floor rather than the 1st floor, but the server sat us down in a corner anyways and got us 2 beers right away. He didn't really let us choose what kind of beer which was kind of odd but either way the beer was good.I got a pretzel to go with our drinks and it was so terrible. Stale and hard. Will definitely pass on this next time.On the bright side, while we were drinking, we got to enjoy live music!

3.5 starsIt checked a box, coming here. Having just gone through the brewery tour outside of Munich the day before, it seemed only natural that we'd stop by the restaurant for food and beer.We arrived at about 11:30 am on a Friday, so restaurant wasn't overly crowded. We did walk towards the back of the building to find a spot to sit, though. Menus are laid out on the tables, and we asked the first person who stopped by for English versions. (I did request English menus in my choppy German, which I think entertained the guy).For my main, I went with the Bierbratl (crisp roasted pork belly with gravy, sauerkraut and a bread dumpling). My husband went with the roast pork with crackling (which came with a potato dumpling and gravy). For our beer choices, I went with a liter of the Winter Special Dopplebock. My husband got a liter of the Hofbräu Original. I'm pretty sure I enjoyed my beer more than my husband. The Dopplebock had a good roasted flavor that helped mask the slight bite. My husband didn't like the Original - it was too light for him, but he had no problem finishing it off.The food was good and very filling. It was also crazy salty. I'm pretty sure that's a German strategy - salty food makes people thirsty, thirsty people drink beer. Anyway - the pork slices had a nice, crispy crust to the skin. The sauerkraut was tangy and the gravy was meaty (and salty). I couldn't do much with the dumpling - it was way too dense and reminded me of my mother-in-law's stuffing.We also flagged down one of the pretzel vendors (for the overly-large pretzel and the chance to take a picture of her in all her pretzel-schlepping glory). We couldn't finish the pretzel either - it was gigantic (and salty), and after all the meat and gravy and beer, it was just too much.At some point during our lunch, the band came out to entertain us. It was fun to hear the traditional music, even though they seemed to play for two minutes and break for seven.I took a star from the rating because our waiter wasn't very friendly, or attentive. To us, at least. I mean - he took his time with the other tables, but left us mostly to our own devices.It was something my husband wanted to do, but after we left, he wasn't too keen on going back. We did stop in the gift shop on the way out, but didn't buy anything. Again, it checked a box, and while I did like my beer, my husband left feeling a bit underwhelmed.

It's definitely a tourist attraction! Thankful to have visited and enjoy the experience, but it's a "now it's done I can cross it off my list" type thing. The food was just okay but you are paying for an experience! As long as you know that before going you will be fine

The epitome of a beer hall. Big beers are awesome and good for even the non-beer drinker. Service was pretty good but it was really hard to find a table. Overall vibe of the place was fun and a great time with your friends.

Great spot for a anyone visiting the city. I was there right at the opening time and got a great spot. It was pretty packed in the first 30-45 min inside and outside. So come early to get a good table. Food was good and beer was great. It is a touristy spot but would not consider it a tourist trap, so definitely stop by to enjoy this place.
The Hofbräuhaus never disappoints and it a "must experience" when in Munich.  If you miss Oktoberfest, the Hofbräuhaus give you a small taste of the experience any day of the year.

Driving and parking in Munich is a nightmare. Yelp says they have onsite parking but that is 100% false. You'll need to park in a garage a few blocks away. Over all wasn't impressed once we made it there. The food was decent the service was rough to say the least. It took us forever to find somewhere to sit. Eventually some folks left their table and we swooped in. We ended up sitting with their dirty dishes in front of us for around 20 minutes before the German couple who we were sharing a table with found someone to complain to them it was cleared away after some eye rolls and frustrated hand motions from our server. They are clearly understaffed. I received a beer fairly quickly but our food took a while. This may have again been due to our frustrated server because others around us got their food despite ordering after us. At some point a polka style band started to play. The music wasn't bad. After around an hour of waiting the food showed up. I wasn't overly impressed with it. We have had a lot of authentic Bavarian food on our trip here and this wasn't anything special. It was worth the trip for the novelty of going because I grew up drinking HB beer in frankenmuth, MI so it was cool to be at the old beirhaus. They're one of the few places in Bavaria that still sells and accepts beer tokens but again.... A novelty. I enjoyed the trip for the beer and novelty but I wouldn't go back.

Oktoberfest 2019! Had an amazing opportunity for to travel to Munich and a lot of Bavaria, including Austria, & Switzerland for 10 days with my wife to spend some time exploring and enjoying the German culture. We stopped into Hofbrau Haus on Day 1 after our flight arrived early and really enjoyed the HUGE pretzels, the Sausages, and the Pork Knuckle that my wife had (amazing). The ambiance was wonderful with a live band playing, the weather was warm and sunny which made the patio a treat. Beer was good and served in the large liter glasses to make sure you are filled to the brim. Many cultural outfits were around that were colorful were everywhere while the atmosphere was jovial and enegetic...so much fun....will definitely go back someday.

Oldest beer garden in Munich and people come in throngs as early as 10am. Its a local institution so just had to check it out. It's a must for the experience if you don't drink beer.- Share a table and converse with complete strangers already drunk when some people are just enjoying coffee and be amused. - Go for the pretzels... massive, real tasty and more than enough to share with your drunk neighbors. - Lively band... man they know how to play and get the crown going. Food looks hearty and delish though we didn't order any. Non alcoholic drinks are also available
It's what you do when in Munich! Food is adequate. It's very hard to get a seat in the biergarten. Enjoyed the experience!

What can you say about the biggest beer garden in the world?   Well, the place itself, with its atmosphere and history alone should be enough to get you to visit.   Only being in Munich for a week, it was something I had at the top of my list and I'm glad I took the opportunity to go.The place is definitely huge.  Floor after floor of tables, traditional German music, and plenty of beer flowing in enormous 1 litre mugs.  If I was reviewing on these things alone, I'd give it 5 stars.The food, however is where it could use a little improving.  I ordered what I figured would be the most traditional German, can't screw it up dish...wiener schnitzel.   It was fairly bland and tasteless, and it came with a tiny potato salad and cranberries (which were both good and I wish I had a bigger portion of that).   It wasn't bad, but just not overly impressive.Munich has some great restaurants, so I would recommend somewhere else for food, but 100% visit Hofbrauhaus for the beer and entertainment.
You've to find your own table. The service was fast. Average price for foods. Good ambiance. The food that I ordered was salty

This is a MUST DO even if you're in Munich for one day.  There's nothing else quite like the Hofbräuhaus experience. It's overwhelming in the best way filled with people drinking, talking and singing.  When you walk in you're faced with seemingly endless (and packed) tables of people. You need to just find a place to squeeze your group in.  Sometimes you'll find an empty table, other times it's time to make some friends.  Once you get a seat it's time to flag down your waiter to order a nice GIANT beer (or whatever your drink of choice is). I found the original to be delicious.  When it came to the food I wasn't overly impressed with the 1 bratwurst I received, considering I only got one, but it was pretty good. But I HIGHLY recommend getting one of those giant pretzels. They were soft and salty and honestly the best part of the meal.  Overall, it's not a place I'd visit regularly because it can feel hectic, but it's definitely an experience and I'd definitely go back if I came back to Munich.

Great local beer served in liter mugs a fantastic menu of very well made traditional German foods and traditional music and garb make this beer hall a can't miss attraction! So why four stars? The oompah music is so loud that if seated in the front half of the building, it literally hurt our ears. That and I agree that the schnitzel my wife ordered was a bit underwhelming. That being said my suckling Pig with gravy and dumpling was fantastic, so tender with crunchy skin and the dumpling was springy gravy absorbing heaven! Of course all the beers we ordered were fantastic and not too filling very easy to drink!As to the noise, the place is huge, we just kept moving further away from the music until we could hear each other speak. Overall, so happy we choose to have dinner at this great local attraction. We would definitely go again!
Amazing beet garden and wonderland service! The food was great and the ambiance was what makes Germany an amazing country.
Atmosphere is great for beer.  Food is meh!Atmosphere is great for beer.  If you are looking for good food and service, go elsewhere.  History, music and beer make this a must see.

This an old establishment that can not be missed. The food is consistent and good but don't expect gourmet cooking. The beer was the best part.  Service is lacking and you have to flag a waiter to get a drink or food. The day we were there they sold out of fried chicken.Also,the courtyard was full of mosquitoes and got a few bite on my legs and arms.
Definitely a place on most people's list of places to visit. It was definitely crowded while I was there. But good drinks great food good fun

The food here is to traditional Bavarian food what McDonald's is to good burgers. Convenience sauces, and they don't even bother to add Krautsalat or parsley to their Schweinebraten because they know their tourist audience will still tip and return home happy with their photos in front of the "authentic" costumed guys with the beers.Prices are what the good versions of the food would be at in less central parts of town.But the interior hall is nice, so why not just sit down, have a large beer or two, and the food elsewhere

Really fun place. I came during Octoberfest. I sat down at about 10:30...about 30 minutes before the officially opened...but they were serving beer. By 11:30 the place was crazy full/busy. Tables were singing and cheering. Everyone there were happy drinks and everyone was friendly and encouraged you to participate in cheers and lots of toasting. With that said I think I know why some people would give poor scores. If you are looking for a quiet place to have a conversation with your friends, this is not the place. If you want to make instant friends, stand singing cheers, and drink a lot of great beer, this is the place for you. I will be back...

Come for the bier and stay for the ambiance! We went to this Bierhaus on a very special night. Apparently on the first Monday of the month bands come to play and people are welcomed to bring instruments and join in. This was the first night in 2 years that they were able to do so after Covid. We were sat upstairs and feeling bummed that we didn't get to sit with everyone one else on the first floor where the hustle and bustle was, but we had no clue we were about to have one of the best nights of our life. We sang, we danced, we ate, drank and made friends. The food was very good and should be considered the standard for Bavaria. We listened to the traditional bands and were lucky to be front and center to watch a world class violinist grace us with a performance that put the room into tears. What an amazing night! Go and get the full experience. We had a reservation for 630 and didn't leave till well after 2 AM.

You can't visit Munich without coming here.Liter mugs of beer. Big pretzels. Schnitzel. This place has the entire biergarten experience you're looking for when you come to Bavaria.Beyond that, the menu has something for everyone, from sausages to the very interesting German-style potato dumpling. The beer is refreshing and the food is great. Keep in mind that seating is a free-for-all. People come and go, so keep your eyes peeled and grab a bench when you can.A must go.

Our server was a ghost after he dropped our first set of beers off. I realize that even if you put all your empty glasses to the side you may need to flag them down but other servers saw this and did not come to serve us, and ours was no where to be found. We don't plan on returning.

We visited Hofbrau after walking around Marienplatz and also because it's a must if you're in Munich! Hofbrau is one of the oldest brewery in Bavaria I believe so it's got history. We seated ourselves and it's a short walk from Marienplatz. We came in shortly after it opened for lunch and there was no one there but damn literally after 30 mins, you wouldn't be able to find a seat anywhere! The place is lit haha during the day and any time really. It's like you're in Oktoberfest even though it's not Oktoberfest so if you're looking for that kind of vibe, definitely come here!Our service was particularly not great because the waiter took FOREVER. But it's fine. It's Oktoberfest, I'll give them that. They give you German menus so make sure to ask for English ones if you don't read German lol. We got roast pork with potato balls and gravy and charcuterie. Both were delicious, I had better roast pork outside of Hofbrau in Germany so I would say it's so-so. I think you come here for experience and the beer - not so much for the food but it will do! I overall liked my experience and would definitely come back here if I'm in Bavaria again!
Went on Christmas Eve. Great food, service and atmosphere. No problem finding a table to join at 9pm.

This place is huge. We came in on a Wednesday evening and it was packed! However, rest assured that you will not have to wait to get a table as you can sit wherever you'd like. Luckily for us, an entire table was available and able to fit all 6 of us. The service is extremely slow because there are very few servers who have to accommodate a whole lot of tables. We ordered a bunch of food; however, what I recall most is of course, THE BEER! My goodness, Munich does not play around with their beer size! *gasp*Highly recommend this place if you're in search of huge beers and good pretzels. However, food was just OK.

This place is more than a place to grab a bite to eat. It is an experience to dine here. The beer is amazing and the service exceeded all expectations. Our table could not see the bottom of a beer stein without another being on the way. The waiter even took some time out to sit down with us and talk to our  poodle. The food was as good as the beer and we hope to stop in to experience again soon.

1 for the food, 5 for the drinks and atmosphere = 3 overall. We made the mistake of making Hofbräuhaus our first destination in München. I can't count how many times our local friends told us in the days following to go for the drinks but avoid the food at all cost. Vegetarian options are limited and unappetizing. The sausages were so bad that we've renamed the place Hotdoghaus. A person I was traveling with, who has a reputation for being a dumpster and willing to eat anything with mustard on it, wouldn't even finish his meal. The pretzels and beer are phenomenal and the atmosphere can't be bought. Stick to the basic beer and pretzels, eat before you go, and have a night to remember.

What a great place with great food! I thoroughly enjoyed eating here and the 1L beers are overwhelming. Delicious beer and delicious food with a great view of the decor and of the musicians playing classic Bavarian songs. The service is not great because it's so busy but if you want attention, you have to flag someone down. If I'm in Munich again, I would definitely give this another visit.

I visited In late September and had a great time. Oktoberfest was cancelled but the place had quite the festive atmosphere and I enjoyed the beer, pretzels, and people watching. I was excited to return on my trip to Munich this week. When I arrived midday I was greeted by a man checking for vaccinations. I showed him my US CDC paper vaccination record and was turned away because I did not have the 'required' QRS code provided to German residents, which as a tourist, is unattainable in Germany (I visited three pharmacies to ask). Each time I was told, that in order to convert paper records to electronic would require that I am a German resident. I asked the pharmacist if establishments required electronic records only and was told that they could indeed, accept paper. I recognize Covid rates are up in Germany but unless this is a company policy, this was unfair for someone to subjectively reject my paper documentation.  As all Americans know, there is no federal government electronic records for vaccination in the US. Anyway, highly disappointed and reduced a five star rating to three. They were happy to accept my US documentation in September when there was lots of money to make but not so much now. I shall burn my Hofsbrauhaus T Shirt when I return home!

Is this touristy? Yep! However, no one can argue the historical significance of the Hofbäuhaus. It's huge, noisy, loud, often chaotic, but something everyone should experience at least once. When people think Bavarian bier, Hofbräu is usually one of the first things that comes to mind. Litre biers and tradition oom-pah music make this an insanely fun place especially for groups though it can be difficult to find a seat when it's really busy. When the server comes to take your order be ready! They move quickly and when it's busy will only return to your table when absolutely necessary.

Ok it gives the authentic Brewery House vibe with its authentic Bavarian folk music band, Steins (or more correctly Maas of 1L Beer) and pretty good food. Lots of selfish people of two hogging tables of 6-8. Pretty awful service by international standards yet they continue to pull in the crowds. Waiting 20 minutes to be served your menu when the place is not mad packed might be a quaint custom but it's kinda antiquated and shouldn't be tolerated as a local custom. But if Bavarian wants to live in the past it can, it serves up good beer just I think there are more local breweries with just the authentic touch but without the hype. The Octoberfest within the Brauhause has just finished. You didn't miss much. :)

A must in Munchen. It's SO big!!! Just come for the beer of your choice, you have to know that it is ALWAYS crowded and loud but worth stopping for a short visit. Un must en Munich. Es TAN grande!!! Simplemente vengan por una cerveza de tu elección, tienen que saber que SIEMPRE está lleno y es ruidoso pero vale la pena una parada corta.

We went to several beer gardens in Munich and this was the best one.  Steeped in history, the building dates back to the 1600s its a beautiful building.  Artwork painted in the ceiling you could spend all day looking at.  The place is huge!Located in a very happening part of Munich there is a lot to do walk around and see both pre & post beers.  Of course the beers are excellent, but they all were.Absolutely worth the visit.

Go for a beer...eat a pretzel.  Get dinner somewhere else.The dinner food is really pretty shameful.  Low quality.  Yes, the place is a tourist trap, but it's like they really stopped trying.  They know they can get away with serving slop to you all...and you will continue to come.  Clearly this establishment has completely sold out.  No pride.
Wonderful atmosphere, just flag down a server, grab a grosse beer and some Essen and enjoy the time and the love music!
What else can I say except that it is a must visit place In Munich that you will enjoy.

Meh... I've been to the Hofbrauhaus in Las Vegas so I had high expectations for the original. But the waiters are rude and impatient. Saw this happening at other tables with other waiters too not just ours. But we were ready (after waiting a while, np on the wait we used that time to make our selections and take in the ambiance not too busy yet for an early dinner with tables empty we found ours as soon as we walked in) and giving him our order without questions or hesitation, a party of 6 and he cut the 4th person as he was telling him what he wanted saying hurry I have a lot of tables. We did turn it around on our waiter though and gave him a taste of his own medicine and started rushing him! He changed his tune real quick especially when we told him we would be saving a lot of money on the tip. After that service was better we did tip well and the food was ok but I personally liked the crispy roast pork at the Oktoberfest Hofbrau tent better. Hofbrau Oktoberfest beer was good all the time but Spaten though...

It's a little touristy but had to eat here while in Munich. This is truly German fare, if you're an American expecting American/German food, this is not the place for you. I got the schnitzel and massive beers. It is rock concert loud, packed elbow to elbow, and there's a great pretzel girl that travels table to table selling German pretzels. It's a very unique experience, a very fun experience, and delicious German food.
Nothing that hasn't already been said. It's a tourist destination and expectations should be set accordingly.  We enjoyed it for what it is.

Best beer in Germany in my opinion. I ordered the pork knuckle and my wife had the half chicken. Both were excellent. They played music and the atmosphere was amazing. If you can't make it to Oktoberfest, but want the experience of one. Come here.
Honestly, Munich was a huge letdown from a culinary standpoint. But I can stand firm and say that Hofbrauhaus was basically the only place I liked. Beer and giant pork shank. What could go wrong?

This place is INCREDIBLE!  The food is awesome, service was great even though the place was packed for Octoberfest!   The beer is very strong so watch out if you're a lightweight. The giant beer mugs must hold close to a gallon of beer. I ordered the schnitzel dinner and it was fantastic.  It came with some bread and sweet red cabbage. My dinner and beer rang up to only 18.5 euros.To know what REAL German tastes like, I had to go to Germany.  American versions of the German restaurant don't even compare.If you're in Munich near the Marienplatz this is the place to go.

3.5 stars for food. 4 stars for atmosphere. Came here for dinner on my first day on Germany. Huge place, with plenty of seating and plenty of people. You basically seat yourself and flag down a waiter to order your food.We tried the sausages with sauerkraut, pork knuckles, schnitzel, pretzel, and beer.Food was OK. Schnitzel was a bit soggy. Pork knuckles was pretty good. Love the crunchy skin. The sausages were alright. Beer was nice. I'm not much of a drinker but I tried a couple sips of the original beer, and it was nice and light. I also tried the non alcoholic wheat beer, and that was nice as well. Light alcoholic taste without the Asian flush.Pretzel is huge, thick and pretty good. You have to get it from one of the girls holding a basket of pretzels to sell. They have live music and restaurant is humongous. They also have a gift shop to buy souvenirs.

Went here with a friend last month and it was super cool to be able to come here! The beers are pretty good and obviously a good size so there were no issues there. The atmosphere was super fun with live music and random people selling dessert pastries and pretzels. My biggest concern is that in the summer, it gets extremely hot in Munich. There is NO ventilation here! Keep this in mind. When you sit down there is no flow of air so be ready. We didn't eat here but judging from other people's food and the prices, I'm sure it's better to eat elsewhere. Otherwise it was such a fun place to be and I can't wait to go back!!

Why 4 stars? Because I can say I did it, but I don't know that I'd need to return.    ---   ---   ---Since Hofrauhaus opened a location in St. Pete, Florida, I feel like it tarnished my experience a bit at this original location. The location in my neck of the woods looks virtually identical, the OG is just larger.One thing I noticed right as we walked in - it smelled like a locker room. I'm not sure if that's the beer, the sausage or the sweaty people inside, but it wasn't the most pleasant aroma, and it was not a subtle smell - it really kicked us in the face as we entered. I definitely don't recommend visiting here if you're looking to have a conversation. It's super loud and it was tough for us to find a seat - definitely be prepared for the communal table situation. And the loudness was mostly due to the band playing nearby, not as much because the patrons were feeling particularly Oktoberfest-y. There was one table who would stand up and yell "AYYYYY" at certain points along with the band, but mostly everyone else was pretty subdued. I was trying to chat with the locals around us, but because it was so loud and because of the language barrier, my wife and I mostly found ourselves just kind of sitting and looking around instead of trying to communicate. She doesn't drink beer and we had just eaten, so I enjoyed one beer and we decided to head out. If you're in Munich, it's probably worth visiting once, especially if you've never been to a satellite location, but hopefully you'll be in a bit more of a party mood than we were on that night.

Hofbrau Haus is one of the great mega temples of beer.  As with Mecca, the Wailing Wall,  the Vatican, all worthy pilgrims make the journey at some point in their life.  Even as a beer infidel, going to Hofbrau Haus I can sense that I am in the presence of something more divine and powerful than my own mortality.   Manly men in Lederhosen rock the upstairs beer hall   with traditional German beer hall music while drunk off their ass patrons sing, scream, eat urinate and suck down unimaginable quantities of amber nectar.  Few experiences will bring you closet to heaven.  I even heard someone praying to a porcelain God in the men's room.Hofbrau Haus's Oktoberfest tent seats 9,991 pilgrims who do their part to consume the 7.5 million gallons of beer that are consumed during the 2+ week Oktoberfest period.  Not to be missed when visiting Munich.

Honestly, it was a nightmare to dine here, especially during covid. There's contact tracing check in at the door and every other table inside is blocked for distancing. There weren't enough tables to seat everyone and you're on your own to find a table to sit once inside.Service was inattentive and took forever to get a menu, order, get food, and pay. They're cash only and the waiter assumed that the €2 change was for him. The food is fine, but skip this Brauhaus, there's so many others within walking distance.

Hofbräuhaus is one the places I've seen all over every major travel website on their to do list in Munich. Essentially I was under the impression that it was the "orientation" for foreigners. We told our German friends and knowing our enthusiasm, they set a reservation! However how busy, loud and generally lack of service in this place makes it feel disorganized. We sat in the outdoor patio area on the second floor. Heads up you're suppose to call or go online a week in advance if you want a reservation. On the day, we called to push back our reservation for 30mins later and fortunately they were nice about it. First, so much meat! Which is German staple to pair with beer. Which is fine, but my friend ordered a large mixed salad and it took them forever to serve it (nearly when the other four of us finished our meal), half hour later. The main entrees in your order will arrive fast in the matter of minutes, so will the beer, but not if you're trying to get something else. The white veal sausages with mustard also arrived half hour later. (side note: the white sausages are usually eaten without the skin. Heard it's because the skin is bad for digestion). We understand that the waiter was busy but the salad and prepared sausage is easily the simplest part of our order. We reminded the waiter three times because it seemed like he forgot about our order. The dark beer with lemonade was interesting and has the fizz of coca-cola. I like sweet foods so it was the interesting part of our meal. Overall I got to learn a lot about German cuisine from my German friends and we had a good time catching up. But we could have a easier time at another beer house in a less crowded location with better service.

Hofbrauhaus is everything wrong and right about a tourist trap.  They have a super large hall that could fit a bunch of people.  They have a live band playing classic German music.  They've got a gift shop filled with all those trinkets your family would love at home.  My first visit I went by myself during the middle of the week around dinner time.  The place was PACKED.  There's a bunch of tables reserved, but everywhere else is open seating.  Even by myself, I had a hard time finding a place to rest.  After finding a spot, I ordered an original 1 L beer and started getting sloshed because it was the first meal of the day.  My neighbor tried the meatloaf and said it was like Spam without the zing.  He didn't finish it, of course I chose another pork knuckle experience.  HB made the most delicious knuckle I've had in Munich.  The skin was crisp and the meat was tender.  The potato dumpling was delectable.  I also ordered veal sausage, which came floating in a vessel of hot water.  Great experience.  My second visit, we sat down and waved for service, but to no avail.  We decided to walk up to the entrance and find a seat there where we were promptly taken care of.  -1 star for that piss poor start.  I don't know what happened this time.  Must be a bad chef back there because the skin on our knuckle was not crisp at all, which was disappointing to my +1.  We also had some yummy wieners with mustard too.  Overall, HB is one of those items to check off your touristy list.  Pick up some neat gifts at the shop while your there.

A place to go to check the block. Food was eh. A little overpriced and standard compared to the price and flavor at most of the mom and pop places around Munich. I would compare it to standard bar food in the states. Same things as most sit down restaurants but watered down in a sense. We lucked out with our group of 6 by getting there around 12 on a Saturday to beat the rush and did not have to wait. Beer is simple and good. Had the original and dunkle. They do have others like the radler and some seasonal choices. The beers come in 1 Ls so you won't have to get a refill often. This works as they are kind of slow at coming around to the tables. More of a place to sit around and have a beer with friends for the nostalgia purpose than the quality of food & beer/ price. I would go again if a new group wanted to go but would stick to other places that are less of a tourist destination.

Sadly, this beer house did not live up to its reputation. We stopped by on a weekday night and it was packed. Finding seating was a bit tricky especially with how big this is but after a few laps around the garden we scored a table. Thank goodness we found a spot outside because inside the hall was incredibly humid and smelled kind of funky.We started off with some beers and then worked up an appetite. My fiancé and his buddy ordered a pretzel, which were extremely hard and stale. They said it was by far the worst pretzel they've ever had. I got the cheese spätzle and it was pretty awful too. Not sure if it had just been sitting out for a while since it was later in the night but it came out cold.Our waiter wasn't the friendliest with us at first (might have been a language barrier) but he eventually warmed up to us towards the end. So the food was pretty disappointing, come for just the beer if anything but it's definitely a tourist trap.

If you are going to come to Munich, you have to make a stop here. It's huge, hectic, and historical. The place is just a classic that you can't pass up. Is there better beer halls? Sure. Are they Hoffbrau? No. You enter and basically find any free seats. You can make reservations but they are in a separate area and you want to be in the cool halls with everyone. You'll meet new people as after a few liters, you will be friends!The beer is crisp and clean. And in this day and age of craft beers with triple hops and peach peanut butter stouts, I found it refreshing. We went with the Originals and the Oktoberfest. The later being the maltier of the bunch. Very good. And from the US bottled ones to compare to, it was less bitter in Germany. The food is traditional German food. Nothing to write about. It is filling and authentic but not the best in town. And that's ok. When in Munich make this a stop. For the beers and atmosphere alone. Prost!

You're not going here for the food because it's your basic German food. You go here for the experience and the beer. Such a fun atmosphere that really encompasses Bavarian culture. If you aren't hungry, you'll be fine getting a Brezel and a Bier and still have a great experience.

The oldest beer house in Munich, it was the last stop of our beer and food tour and it is also known as a place frequented by Adolf Hitler during his early political years. We returned here to try authentic Bavarian food, and we definitely got authentic European service. We were ignored by several waiters we tried to wave down several times until someone was kind enough to seat us. Once we sat, it took 20 minutes before a waiter even entered the room so we waved down the host. Once we got a server, though, he was very attentive. We started with the obazda cheese, I ordered the pork and dumpling, and my wife ordered the vegetable quiche.The cheese was soft and delicious and it had a unique taste. The pork was cooked well, but the sauce was flavorless and the dumpling was bland. The vegetable quiche had a good potion of vegetables inside with a salad on the side that had a light dressing. The pastry itself was not very flavorful. She ended up picking the vegetables out to avoid the rest. With poor service and below average food, maybe try this place out for beers and go to another restaurant for authentic Bavarian food.

This place is PACKED. It was also Oktoberfest weekend in Munich, so it was to be expected. We ended up eating outside and the wait was understandably a bit long. They didn't seem to have English menus, so we used Google translate on some things (it's been 15 years since my German class, so I need a pass lol) A few of us got the pork knuckle (Schweinshaxe) that came with a side of dumpling. It was enough for my husband and I to share though getting the meat off of it was not an easy process. OMG the fat is so crispy and tasty. It's an absolute MUST TRY aside from schnitzel in Germany. Many, if not all of the major brewhouses seem to have them. Everything was quite tasty and the service was good, so no major complaints here.

This is my favorite restaurant I've been to in Germany. The atmosphere is fun and they play awesome German music. You seat yourselves. We sat down and a waiter was very quick to come over and help us. He didn't speak much English but he was still really helpful. They have English menus which is nice. We all enjoyed our meals. The restaurant is also in a good location.

The place to come for festivities! Visited here during the evening time and I would recommend eating outside as it was stuffy and felt like a sweaty sauna this place is huge and can pack a lot of people. The outside courtyard is also very big and has a second level with additional outdoor and indoor seating. I loved walking in and hearing the live band it really set the mood. The food and drinks here were great and the pretzel is not on their menu. There are some ladies that walk around selling them and you can purchase the pretzels from them.

This was a great experience for my study abroad group. We wandered around the Hofbräuhaus on a Friday night and it was wild. There were people everywhere having a great time. We have a large group so our reservation was on the third floor which was a massive dining hall. The service was good considering how many people were in the restaurant, but the food was nothing to get worked up about. We also got to hear the Umpa band right next to us and "whip" music a couple of times which was really loud, but fun to watch. This is a must visit in Munich.

I was pretty excited in general to check out Hofbrauhaus. Finally getting over my jet lag and feeling like a normal person again, we entered after a full day wandering all over Munich. First thing is first, the checklist...Live music? Yep.Beer hall? Yep.Beer garden? Yep.Food? Yep.Beer by the liter? YAS.I have to say the food was just average in my opinion, but what they lack in food they make up for in ambiance. The live band was great. Some people dancing and just about everybody day drinking on a Sunday. Seating is self serve and I would definitely say it's quite the mix of locals and tourists. Also English menus at hand if needed and each of the servers seemed to understand English which made it easy for us to communicate. For food, I ordered the roast pork with crackling served with homemade natural gravy and a potato dumpling. I probably would've went with some sort of sausage or pork knuckle but I'd been ordering quite a few of those over the past few days so I thought I'd give the roast pork a try. While it was quite juicy and tender, easily would've preferred a pork knuckle or a sausage plate after a few bites. The potato dumpling, not sure what it is about it but just not a fan of potato dumplings in general.For beer, I did a liter of their dark beer. Surprisingly not as filling as one might think and I was able to put it down with no problem along with my food. Talk about crushable. Anyways, it was an enjoyable experience and definitely a must do when in Germany... visit a beer garden and have a liter of beer. Cross that off the bucket list.'Til next time, cheers!209/365
Portionsweise were a bit on the small side and my meat was very dry. I guess this is to be expected from a tourist attraction.

Food: 3.5/5.0Service: 3.5/5.0Value: 3.0/5.0Decor: 3.5/5.0Overall: 3.5/5.0Food was good, except for the pork knuckle which seemed like the animal wasn't fully bled.  The other dishes were pretty food.  Service was helpful, but it helped that I was there for a weekday lunch.  Wouldn't mind returning if in the area.

No visit to Munich would be complete without a visit to the Hofbrauhaus. This iconic beer hall/restaurant carries so much history not only for Germany, but for Bavaria.Even though the hall is large, they do a pretty good job at serving you and making sure your liter of beer doesn't get empty. As with most halls, seating is family style which means you will make fast friends with your neighbors.I would recommend visiting during the weekday evenings to get the full effect (including the band) -- but still being able to find a seating (especially if you are traveling with a group of folks).

The greatest and most fun beerhall I've ever been to!!!  Is it touristy? YES!  But locals go there too.  Is it loud and crowded? YES!  Is the beer a little pricey? YES!  But who cares?  Hofbrauhaus is awesome.  Walking into Hofbrauhaus is stunning. It's huge. Massive. It's packed with people enjoying plentiful beer and the company of hundreds of other people. Bavarian music played by the  live band in the center of the room surrounds you. And so surprisingly beautiful. We were stunned by the vaulted, beautifully painted ceilings.It was Friday night, but we found seats at a long table shared with people from the UK, Ireland and Germany. Sharing beer with strangers is half the fun of a beer garden.  We ordered our big Hofbrau beers and settled in surrounded by great oom pa pa music and the roar of the crowd. It feels like Oktoberfest come to life every day.  Our waiter was great. SO MUCH FUN!  Hofbrauhaus is everything you didn't know you wished existed near your own house. You'd never find such attention to community, architecture and beauty in the US. Not a tv in sight. Go here for a fun evening in Munich.

Really enjoyed this place.  I feel it was a pretty reasonable tab.We had the Bavarian Cheese appetizer, 6 beers, 2 bottles of water, suckling pig, and a 1/2 order of Pig knuckle. The whole bill was under €100.  For a place that has such a large volume of tourists, these prices really surprised me.  I expected it to be a lot more.The server was very friendly. And the overall atmosphere was really nice.  I recommend making a reservation if you don't want to wait in line.  We went on a weekday.  It was busy early when we got there at 8pm, then tapered off quite a bit by the end of our meal.Lastly, the food was delicious.  The serving size was more than enough.  Very happy with it.

Hofbrauhaus was everything we expected. Great food (you have to try the pork knuckles), lively atmosphere with live music, and of course great beer. When in Germany you must go to Hofbrauhaus or you didn't really experience Germany. Also, try out one of their massive pretzels.

Definitely a place worth going to when in Munich. Hofbrauhaus is a fun beer hall that has tons of history attached to it, dating back to the 1500's! Can be a bit confusing at first when you first enter, but you can just go sit wherever there is an open bench seat and a server will come up to you to take your drink order and then food order if you also want to eat. Their original (lager) beer was pretty good. We got the Roast Pork Belly dish and their Weiner Schnitzel and they were both pretty good as well. The best? Probably not. You come to Hofbrauhaus for the experience, definitely not for the food. Super touristy but you'll have some crazy fun here!

It's almost a rule that one must go drink a beer and eat German food at this classic, historic beer hall! So, while in vacation in Munich, that's exactly what we did! FOOD: After finding a table nestled in the corner, we decided to start our evening by enjoying a stein of beer and a basket of warm pretzles. So delicious!! And with so many entree options, my husband and I had a hard time deciding what to order! We finally decided to try the Wienerschnitzel and Bavarian Roast Chicken. Both served with potato salad and cranberries, we were set! The meat was tender and flavored perfectly.  SERVICE: Our server was attentive, fun and outgoing. Not to mention, all the waitresses carrying 8-10 steins filled with beer around to the tables was impressive! SPACE/ATMOSPHERE: The space is huge!! With multiple halls and rooms, I was amazed with how massive the space was! The atmosphere was upbeat and fun. With a live band playing Bavarian music, and the ceiling painted with beautiful murals, the space comes to life and the vibe is energetic and fun. Although it's definitely a tourist spot, make sure not miss it! You won't be disappointed!

Although this is a tourist destination, we found it enjoyable. There is a large outside bier Garten. The main dining room had a German band playing which made the atmosphere fun. We were here for lunch so it was mello. We saw plenty of locals that had their own steins.One piece of advice, get the pretzel from the girls walking around. The pretzels on the menu were just ok

When you're traveling to Bavaria, this is the place to stop by to take it all in; Bavarian beer, music and food. The ambiance is something you cannot find elsewhere. Hofbräuhaus is only four blocks away from Marienplatz. Once you walk in, you can basically just sit at any bench as long as they're not reserved. Flag a server and order your beer and food. I do recommend Schweinsharxe (a roasted ham hock) and Lammwurst to go with your beer.

In the middle of the city center - CheckLots of room to sit down and mingle - CheckDiverse crowd, fun people watching - CheckReasonably priced beers the size of your head - YASSS!!!While in Munich this is a must-see even if you only stop in for a couple beers and a snack. When you enter you likely won't find a hostess or server to seat you. We just sort of followed some guys in and sat at an open table. They have long tables that encourage social interaction with strangers which I think is fun. The service was sort of slow, not very friendly but that is ok too. We were mainly here for the experience and people watching. A gal will come around with giant pretzels or other yummy carb goodies for 2€. Right before we left a band was starting to play. Also there is an on site gift shop that sells beer steins and mugs for outrageous prices:)I love Munich!

Crazy experience coming from the U.S. granted I came urging the first few days of Oktoberfest so it might have been more "extra" for the crowds. The beer stein  was massive. Lots of German food- lots of meat with a few veggie options. The only vegan option might be the pretzel which was also massive and delicious. My friend and I went upstairs and enjoyed the live music rather than staying downstairs with the massive crowds. Beer was good, crisp and light. I'm. It a big beer drinker but it was mild enough for my pallet.

Racist and gross AVOID IF YOU ARE BROWN. My husband and I are brown and came from San Francisco and decided to check this place off our list because it was a highly recommended watering hole in Münich. The waiting staff didn't take our order until 20 minutes of us sitting there and the other caucasians that came after us all got their orders taken. I can't believe something like this is happening in 2023, this wouldn't even happen in the remotest of mid-west small towns in the US. One thing this place had going for them was fortunately the beer. We tried the hofrbräu original and it was decent. But the experience overall was garbage. Oh, we tipped the waiter as much as the beer costed, so no idea what's going on here. Are these people traumatized and acting out? We will never know, because we are not coming back ever.

You know what you're getting into if you go here. It's one of the five original big breweries in Munich. during Oktoberfest it's one of the tents that everyone tries getting into. This is an amazing experience. The ones in the USA look the same as the one in Munich. The food is excellent, the service is excellent, and it gives you the quintessential German beer experience.

Have to go here when in Munich. Beer is good. Food is average at best.  Music is traditional German music. Lots of overpriced souveneirs. Yes we bought some. Women walking around selling pretzels and bread. 5 euros a pretzel. Very crowded. Tourists squeeze togetherat tables. We have a hofbrauhaus in Northern Kentucky just like this with better food.

This is a review of the food, as we didn't have any drinks.  The Whole Roasted Knuckle of Pork was disappointing. The meat was not fall off the bone tender but the flavor was good.  The potato dumpling was too dense for my taste. The Weinerschitzel was just okay as it was a little bland. The potato salad was okay, but a cold side wasn't to my liking.The service was average.  I wouldn't recommend the restaurant as I think it is a tourist oriented eatery.
Cyndy's Bottom Line:  Fun tourist beer hall with solid food.Great beersDelicious schnitzelFriendly fun service

I loved this place!  We came here after dinner (and only had our drinks here). This place was lively with loud and interesting crowds (from local to tourists). My local colleagues taught me to sing the drinking songs and banging on the table at appropriate time. The waiter kept the drinks flowing and I had a hard time getting off the bench when we were ready to leave.The glass was heavy even when I was totally sober. The beer was great but I forgot the "big" volume of it in the glass. As result, despite only with 3 rounds, I found myself a bit "loosened" - and joined many of the singing and loud jokes with my follow diners around me.  This will be my "regular" spot if I come back to Munich again.

Dang this place is hugeee! Showed up on a Friday with a large group (about 25) during the early evening and with much luck snagged a few tables all next to each other! There is a big indoor area as well as an outdoor area... and it was full! Definitely a fun place to check out if you're visiting Munich. I'm not much of a beer drinker (I know, I know) but I somehow managed to make nearly 1 liter of the drinkable Hofbrau Original disappear. For food I ordered a side of sauerkraut and a side of spaetzle (vegetarian over here, hi). Several minutes later our waiter returned and said the spaetzle was "out of order." Damn it. Okay on to Plan B, the homemade vegetable pie "garnished" with salad it was. But oops I forgot that I had ordered the sauerkraut. So. Much. Food. I was expecting the vegetable pie to be like a pot pie of sorts but it ended up being kind of like a rectangle of mixed veggie, cheesy, eggy quiche with a borderline soggy crust. Unfortunately it wasn't hot hot (temp) but it was still satisfying. The green salad was a nice fresh note. The sauerkraut was served hot (for some reason I was expecting cold kraut) but it was super flavorful and I enjoyed it enough.Our waiter wasn't great, but I personally would rather be a plumber than attempt to deal with the chaos of Hofbrauhaus, so no real complaints. Oh, and my arms are definitely not strong enough to carry all of those ginormous beers. Prices are decent, but definitely not cheap.Overall, I'd say check it out once with a group of friends and you'll probably have a good experience overall.

I now understand why this is the go to for most tourist for a German tourist experience.   They have a live band at night playing exotic German music in lederhosen, 1 litre steins of beer and giant pretzels that are truly delicious.   There is no bar at this place.   You get a long table and you sit with strangers if you are by yourself or in a small group.  But most people here are friendly.  The servers know how to direct you through their menu if you have never been there and are good at answering your questions.   US dollars are accepted at this bar!   I tried their homemade wieners and they were decent.  Their sauerkraut was very good.   It's better to share some of the food at your table, even if it is with strangers because that pretzel is a lot to eat by yourself.   Literally it is the size of your head almost.  It is worth going back.

This place had a great atmosphere and is absolutely huge! It's definitely a must visit when in Munich! First of all, you walk through these massive doors and you enter into this hall that initially doesn't seem to be that big. But once you keep walking you realize that it keeps on going! There are so many halls attached to the main hall and the main hall has a German band playing traditional German music! Also, it's PACKED. Even when we got in at like 5pm it was already completely full in the main hall so we had to sit in one of the side halls.Everybody is a bit tipsy and there are a ton of tourists, but overall it's a good time. There are a ton of servers here too and they're really quick in bringing out the foods and drinks. They were super friendly, helped explain things and were very patient even though you can tell they were super busy, so I really appreciate that!They have a huge menu - so many options. We came here and got their infamous 1L beers. I had the dark beer and it did taste interesting and was good but didn't blow my mind. Even though I've never had German dark beer before I knew that there must be better places from what people described. The food here was sort of mediocre too, we had the classic dishes: bratwurst and sauerkraut, pork knuckle, pork belly and potato dumplings. The pork knuckle was really hard to eat, and wasn't cooked perfectly. The other foods were a bit better but still didn't have that much flavor or freshness. We got the pretzels and it was tough and tasted stale. We also had dessert and this was pretty tasty though! The Kaiserschmarrn (fried donut) was pretty good though!Overall, it was a good experience, but I probably wouldn't go back. It seems like a places that's sold out and is cashing in as a tourist destination.

So much fun and a MUST when you're in Germany. Big beers and pretzels! Limited food options if you only eat poultry but there is a rotisserie chicken option (pictured) which was pretty good! After so much beer food is always a good idea.Seating is limited but just keep an eye out and something will open. Service is pretty good for being so nuts! Have fun! Prost!

This is one of those places that you have to visit because of it's reputation as being German.  I've been here as a tourist in the ground-level hall, and for private events in the upstairs rooms.  Once the novelty wears off, I've found it to not be such a big deal.  The beer is OK, but it's not the best in Munich (I prefer the Augustiner, either across the street from Hofbrau, or the larger one on Neuhauser Strasse, Food in any of the beer halls is OK at best.  Go in for a beer, listen to the band, then go out and enjoy Munich.  If you can get upstairs, take a look at the large hall and imagine it full of rowdy revelers!  It's a must-see, but not a "stay too long" kind of place.

Lots of fun, lots of history here too. I only removed stars because I legitimately had the absolute WORST customer service experience I have ever had at the store trying to purchase a long sleeve. If I could rate only the store, I would give it a zero if possible. The woman I politely asked for help about where to find a long sleeve was the meanest and most rude individual I have ever met in my life lmao. Please be prepared to potentially run into this woman.

meat meat and more meatThis has an atmosphere you won't find anywhere else. Dark with long wooden tables and waitresses carrying 4 or 5 litre steins. The best dish in the house is the Schweinhaxl (Knuckle of pork) with the crispy fat left on. If you're a crackling fan, this is orgasmic. Be sure to bring your appetite as it is massive. great selection of sausages too.Quite rowdy when the locals get going. Amazing how much beer a German can drink! Nearly as much as me and my colleagues.

While a lot of fellow travelers condemn this place as "touristy," I'd like to remind all you prospective visitors that we are all TOURISTS researching this place, after all! (If you're that into 'living only like the locals do,' perhaps you should visit 45 minutes outside of Munich and eat at local cafes.) **Annoyed rant over** While it DOES get crowded with many tourists, it does so for a reason! The beer garden oozes with Bavarian character, with live music playing, delicious spaetzle/wurst cooking, and huge steins of delicious beer up for the drinking. It's a rare peek into German culture and a fun excuse to drink a liter of beer with friends. While I am fiercely defending this place after having a great time, you'll need to be smart about planning your visit here. I will admit that the place gets very crowded and very drunk, so coming by on weekdays or non-peak hours will better help you secure your own table and faster service.

Delicious, authentic , culturally traditional food.The beer is amazing who knew my son wld drink lemonade light beer. The portions were amazing Service and environment was friendly and fast even though it feels like there's a 1000 people in there waiting to eat

I must give this place five stars for it is quite the well run machine. This is a historic bier Haus and they still have a lot of the old time flare, yet with efficiency of the modern day. Incredibly large and heavy beer mugs but today I had the beef stew and it was melt in your mouth delicious. Wide selection of bier as you can imagine but also Live entertainment from the old world to keep your spirits up. The wait staff was also very efficient. This is a must see place when you are in town.

Four stars for the beer!! Holy cats the Hofbrau Original Dark Beer is amazing. I could have sat there all day and sipped on a few liters. The beef goulash was very salty- almost too salty to eat. But my HB fried sausage and sauerkraut dish was very tasty. The sauerkraut almost tasted sweet. Yum!! We easily found an open table when we got there around 5PM on a weeknight. Service was frustrating. When we finally flagged down a waiter, he managed to bring us beer, but then refused to let us pay with a credit card and had us pay with cash. We were confused... so I double checked their website and confirmed that they accepted cards. We saw him do this with other tables around us as well. The next time the waiter came back (20ish mins), we asked to order food and pay with a credit card and he said okay. ??? Lol. It's a fun place to do once, and experience the beer hall atmosphere.

A Múnich must see. Get the Large 1L beer. After that get the white sausage ( it taste so much better than it looks), then purchase a giant pretzel from one of the waitresses walking around.   The atmosphere is amazing. You can't go wrong with this place.

The Hofbräuhaus is an undisputed landmark, a must visit site in Munich, and has a reputation for being the best known beer hall on Earth. All that lends itself to being a tourist trap, for all the good and bad that comes along with it.You won't get a sense of the true size of this place until you step inside. Once you do, it's kind of hard to grasp: the Hofbräuhaus is absolutely immense. The main hall alone seats over 1300, with many more occupying the other rooms and the sizeable beer garden. You can (and I did) spend a good twenty minutes just searching for a place to sit if you come during Oktoberfest. I found a relatively quiet bench inside and got my order in: the wursteller (a kind of sausage sample plate) and a half litre of dunkel (a dark lager). The gruff waiter took my order and the food came out surprisingly quick. Unfortunately, it was just so-so. That plate came with two small pieces of Vienna sausage (think a natural casing hotdog with a bit more bite to it), a piece of long, coarsely ground spicy pork sausage, and a thicker, finer pork sausage, all on a heap of sauerkraut. Not a great meal for €18, but the beer and the experience were a must.

I think it's the most famous place in Munich to try the specialties.It's very crowded but you can find seats easily. I feel like this place is full of locals and tourists.We had some beers and it was good like in most of the places in Germany.The traditional German food is mainly composed of potatoes and meat and cabbage! My boyfriend went for the roasted pork with potatoes dumplings and I had the chicken breast.It was good and we had a lot of fun there with the music band.

A great experience that you should try once. Their seating and ordering system is chaotic, the wait times are long and the service attitude is mixed.My suggestion is keep it simple by finding some room to sit yourself and not being shy to cozy up with others. Order some beers from the staff (who you have to consistently flag down) and pretzel from the lady offering them who walks around the hall.

Tourist Trap?Visit #1: Initially I thought this was a big tourist trap...but right in front of the Ommpah band, we met local Munichens Bert and Ernie(I made up those names, can't remember their real names!).   It was crowded, but they invited my wife and I to share their table. These two German gentlemen have coming here for 40+ years, since the beginning of their friendship. We hung out with then for almost an hour. They're married, but their wives insist they have some man time with each other, to keep the Bromance going. Every Thursday afternoon they ride their bikes here, chat, meet new people, listen to some music, drink a couple liters, and then ride their bikes back home(about 4km) in time for dinner. We talked about life, politics, friendships, travel, philosophy...I love meeting locals, its one of my favorite parts about travel! Visit #2: We were a group of 10, and it was a long wait to get a table on the first floor...but the second floor was half empty and quiet. No oompah band unfortunately, but you can get table quickly.  No very exciting, but the food and beer are still good. Beers here are about €4-8 depending on the type and size(GET 1 LITER!!!), food is €10ish for the basic sausage plates to €20+ for the fancier plates...try a roast pork knuckle! Pretty pretzel girls walk around selling giant pretzels for about €4...Experiences can vary depending how and when you visit, and with whom...either way, check it out if you're in Munich.

I dined here back in October 2016. I will come back to this place, I promise.Come for the history, cultural significance, and the experience. Stay for the pork knuckles and beer.Expect some delayed service, relax, its a beer hall. Its not fast food, its traditional Bavarian food. Sit next to someone you don't know, don't mind if they ignore you. Its all good. Don't be awkward and try to talk, just chill and bounce to the umpa band.Prost!

It was very packed when I went, but we managed to find seating out in a balcony area. The beer was delicious and the food was great! I got the oktoberfest dark draft and some shnitzel with a giant pretzel. Everything was cooked to perfection and the gravy made everything better. The pretzel was to be expected and delicious with some cheese. The beer was the definite winner and the ambiance of the place just can't be beat! Well worth the trip considering it was what I had in mind when passing through Munich

Late Sept 2021.  Figured it'd be too crowded mid-day this time of year, but that wasn't the case. The courtyard with the band was full, but otherwise the restaurant was wide open. We were able to get an inside table with a view to the courtyard without waiting. The food was decent as was the beer. Service was excellent.
Great food. Great beer. Great service. Our group had a wonderful evening here. Will return if I'm back in Munich.
This place was touristy, but I honestly thought it had decent food and service.  It's such a fun environment as well.  Worth going at least once!

Had the schnitzel again and it was MARVELOUS. That coupled with the sauerkraut and the Dunkel Beer made this meal a home rub. Substituted the potato salad out for sauerkraut and that helped me satisfy another craving . Has a very "homemade" feel to it.

Kind of in a rut when it comes to Hofbrauhaus. Always order the same thing and ALWAYS leave happy. While I am not really a big beer drinker anymore I start with the 1L Dunkel and manage to drink my way through it accompanied with a large pretzel with the packaged mustard which is to die for. Finish with the Wienerschnitzel with German potato salad and red cabbage. Could never ask for anything more although if you have ever seen the Schweinen Hocks that may elicit a try sometime.

Stopped in during Oktoberfest and had a great time.  Very loud, fun atmosphere, neat architecture, service was good, beer was of course amazing, and the food was good too - got the pork knuckle and weinerschnitzel.  I had more fun at the real Oktoberfest, but if I was in Munich at another time of year, I'd definitely come here for the Oktoberfest feel.

This review is purely for our terrible waiter with attitude, that would not serve us until 25 mins after being seated--and the fact that he told us the kitchen was closed, even though everyone was being served food almost 30 mins after he brought our drinks.  Wish I got his name, but of course he had his name tag hidden inside his lederhosen.I wish I could've at least sample some type of food, but the only thing available to my group of friends was Radler's in all 3 forms.  Refreshing lemonade with beer.  Though that left a sour taste in my mouth for the rest of the evening.This place gets packed to the brim and it is definitely a tourist hub.  I would avoid it if possible and seek something more local if your in the area.

If your visiting München then Hofbräuhaus is a right of passage you have to go. There's something about the community you find at the tables. Servers running around with liters of beer. It's a cool experience but don't expect good food. It's averaged prices so it's not to upsetting but my chicken was extremely dry it was difficult to eat without water. Service takes forever like at most German restaurants so just be ready to wait. This isn't somewhere you go while in a hurry. Overall cool experience, but bad food.

This was exceptional. We had a idea what to expect, crowds, but this was almost overwhelming. You sit with random people you will never see againAnd have a sparkling little talk over huge one liter beers and sausages and sauerkraut. Don t forget the bread basket..and the Goulash is superior if you ask for boiled potatoes instead of a dumpling.. Our table mates were from Moscow Russia. And here we are in the beer house that Hitler chose to launch the Nazi party. And 200 tables are original. Wow what a place. What a decor.what atmosphere.And the band played on...Thanks  google translate.

Our group of 13 was able to find seating and a couple different tables, and that's showing up at 5pm on a Thursday night. We all settled in for our cold plates, hot plates, and pork knuckle. I went with the knuckle, which isn't as good as it comes in Munich, but was certainly more than edible. Would I go back next time I visit Munich? No, I wouldn't - but staff were friendly enough, especially considering they have to spend their days serving annoying, drunk tourists. :)

This would be one of the most memorable things I did in Munich. Considered as the best beer hall in the world, you would see a lot of tourist flocking and dining. Women wearing dirndl whil men wearing lederhosen made you transport to oktoberfest.Scrolling through all the reviews here, a lot of people mentioned that they were not catered for a very long time, most of the reasons point out that there's no designated person to serve them. It wasn't the case for us, it might be because we went there after lunch time. We were immediately served and we were well looked after. We understood that with the amount of people, we would be probably wait longer just to be served but we were very committed to trying the dishes of Hofbrauhaus especially its famous pints so no matter the circumstances, we will wait patiently. Funny thing is I was also doing my grad school course requirement while waiting so it doesn't bother me as muchJust be patient if you really want to experience the beer hall. Remember it's a tourist spot, a lot of people all over the world would come and dine in.

My review is a little late , perhaps I'm still hungover  but What's an experience!! Oktoberfest in the mother land!! Awesome time awesome people!! Place is huge! This is my second time here and it never disappoints me!! Grab a table and let your eyes ears and heart be your guide. Hofbrauhaus is amazing!! Live laugh and travel for beer!!

I really enjoyed my experience here.While there are no shortage of famous beer halls in Munich, this place is one of the "must-see's" for a variety of reasons.  Reputation aside, the Hofbrauhaus is a Munich institution featuring cavernous digs full of communal seating, loud patrons and huge servings of beer and local German favorites.Basically if you're in the mood to get the whole beer house experience, you can't go wrong here.  I wouldn't say the food blew my mind but some of the sausages were definitely very tasty.  The pretzel here was gigantic and the huge servings of beer will definitely put you in a good (and bloated) state in a short period of time.  This place is often packed to the brim and it can definitely feel touristy at times.  But one can't deny how much fun it is to be here, eating the food, soaking in the fun ambiance and drinking some kick ass Hofbrau lager.  During my time in Munich, the Hofbrauhaus was definitely one of the most memorable aspects of my trip.  While I'll definitely hit up more beer houses on my next trip, I will most certainly come back here again as well!

Busy place and definitely touristy.  Fun stop just to say you have been here but does not feel like a chill traditional Bavarian beer hall, because of all the people rushing around and lines of people and tour guides walking through the Schwemmel.  We enjoyed ourselves drinking the half liters of Dunkel and  original beer.  The pork sausage links with sauerkraut was good and my son ordered a jhang roasted chicken was good, but the potato salad was just ok.  Great place to take in the history, and get loud, but not a place to sit back and relax to enjoy a beer with food.

This place is obviously a tourist trap, but who cares?  This is like a cathedral for wonderful beer.  The service was great, the atmosphere was warm and welcoming, and the food was fantastic.  There are few better ways to spend an afternoon than having a mas and a plate of obatzda with great people.

It's our first time in Munich and I feel this is a must/do when in town. The atmosphere is lively, there's live music even at 4pm. Service is so-so, some servers are timid and refuse to engage I think due to language barrier. Beer is 8 euro and main dishes start at 12 euro up. We enjoyed the vibe, the people-watching and we welcomed the slow service as it was a good break for our tired feet. It is a German Hard Rock Cafe with merchandise of all kinds bearing the name. Free use of toilets too which is getting rare in Europe.
A dream come true for my brother and I to come here.  Beer was incredible, but the entire space was so beautiful that we were floored .  I hope to return one day.

Go do the tourist thing and have yourself a beer and make new friends.  First of all it's a free-for-all. Find a place to sit as no one will escort you to a table.  If you are already sitting at a table move over and make room for others so it's not so awkward. Once seated it does take a while for the waitress to get your order.  I recommend ordering food and drink all at once especially if it's busy.  I knocked a star off because we waited 40 minutes to order just beer and all the food was all sold out.

It is a bit cliched, but it has to be experienced. Hofbrauhaus is steps away from Marienplatz, so it is very convenient to work into a walking tour of the city center. The place is huge, with giant beer hall style seating downstairs, a giant outdoor patio, and more space upstairs for special occasions. We came late on a chilly Friday night and enjoyed a beer and giant pretzel on the patio. They come in liter size only, and the dunkel was our preference. It went down smooth with the pretzel, which is served by a pretzel maid who walks around with a basket full of the good stuff. We also ordered obazda from the waiter, which is tasty cheese that comes with its own slice of rye bread, but it was much better slathered on the pretzel.Even better, they had a band playing traditional tunes, which set a great scene. Hard to imagine people have been enjoying this place for nearly 500 years, so do yourself a favor and join mankind's unbroken beer lineage.

The international Hofbrauhaus (HB) in Munich is a lot fun with music and dancing. It is located in the heart of the City of Munich. I would say make reservations to dinner show is the best to experience this wonderful germ. This is Bavarian region food. It is a lot of different than many Germany cities food. Be ready of your stomach because you are going to ride out the food and beer at this place with wonderful celebration night. The beer here is awesome and fresh since the brewery is next to it. I like their Hofbrau Original beer has a very great taste of it. The food include roast pork with cracklings, roasted pork knuckles, sausages and more. The entertainment is very fun with audience participation. I like the ribbon dance. One wrong move or step, the ribbon will not wrap the pole with correct pattern. Wood chopping with their wood chip flying to our table. The show also present the cow bell music with hand eyes coordination. Overall I recommend you book this event 1 week earlier before you come. It is fun to drink at their beer garden and eat at their restaurant.

Oh the famous Hofbrauhaus, everyone talks about, visits it, and either runs at the first sight of the large crowds or joins in on the fun. I decided to take the journey and experience an old cultural experience that has slowly vanished these days in Germany. So to cut to the chase, yes expect a TON of people and sometimes a long wait. I honestly walked in, circled a few times and found a seat outside as inside was nearly impossible to find a seat. As with many German restaurants, no dilly dallying allowed when it comes to ordering. Menus were on the table (English included), and it was pretty straight forward in terms of what to expect. I of course did my due diligence and looked ahead of time, but I was already suck on the baked pig knuckle. My travel partner ended up getting a sampler plate of sausages and sauerkraut. Flagged a server who could care less about friendliness, but honestly I'd be worn out with the crowds at this famous restaurant as well.  Put in our order with a couple of beers and of course purchased a giant pretzel from one of the many employees walking around with a large baskets of pretzels. Food and beer came out pretty quickly, which had me a tad skeptical in terms of food delivery, but that was quickly shot down with I sunk my teeth into the fred flinstone sized pig knuckle. Extremely tender, crunchy skin, wonderful sauce and over all a complete mouth-gasm. I wish I could consume them daily, but I am pretty sure the flight cost to Munich would bankrupt me after awhile! My travel partner had some tasty sausage, but the sauerkraut was the real winner honestly, very tasty with a nice touch of caraway seeds to add some punch. As for pricing, yes it is not a cheap eat, but an authentic German feast, and I would gladly do it again in a heartbeat!

Been here a lot, typically with people who have never been to Munich before. If you have never been, you must go, primarily because everyone will swear that you must stop there, but one trip will last a lifetime.While this is one of the more iconic spots in Munich, it has become more of a tourist attraction than a place to eat and drink. They push the larger beers (Maß), instead of the smaller half liters; my guess is that because of the crowds and how busy it typically is, this prevents them from having to come to the tables as often. The food is mediocre; my advice is that if you are hungry, eat somewhere else and just come here for a bier.I found the schnitzel to be uninspiring and the schweinhaxe was overpriced for what you got. Clearly there are better meals to be had in Munich, but as a tourist attraction, put it on your list.
