Most evenings will also have live music but never too loud that it drowns out conversations.The tables are community tables, like ever beer hall in Germany, but when you sit at these tables you are rarely sitting with Germans, you are most likely sitting with people from other countries as well, so if you want to talk to Germans about German things, you'll be out of luck. But you will have an opportunity to find out more about Spain, Greece or other countries from the folks around you.

So this place seemed very disorganized. There's no system to getting seated, you just have to kind of walk around the really busy restaurant, watching the tales like a hawk to swoop in when someone gets up. It's pretty awkward, because you don't want to make people feel like you're rushing them. They need a waiting list or a host at least. The food was good, the nonvegan menu items looked really good and the big pretzels were expensive but tasty. They had no vegan menu items besides a side salad. I asked if the side of salted potatoes had butter on them, and my server replied "I think so" so, not a good sign. Small-ish glasses of water were €2,90 (Over 3 US dollars) ...Overall, I guess it was worth the experience because it's a really famous place.

Probably the best known beer hall in Munich.   Stopped in during my visit during Oktoberfest.  Joined a large group at a long table on the 3rd floor not far from the band on stage.  Sampled my 1st pork knuckle and potato dumplings which were salty and good with the dark beer that I was drinking.  As many have stated, the food wasn't 5-star, but it was fulfilling while drinking copious amounts of beer.  Servers were busy, but friendly enough, and attentive.  Prices were reasonable.  Check it out when visiting Munich.
It seems like mass chaos at first, but it's awesome! Excellent beer, of course, and food to die for! Try the roast pork with potato dumpling. Walk around and enjoy the decor, it's full of life.

I stopped in here with my boyfriend for dinner while visiting Munich. We sat at a long table and were happy to hear the band and all the fun people around singing. The menu was pretty large and everything was delicious. The service was also very fast and attentive considering how many people were inside. They accept credit card. I'd recommend a visit and had a very fun time.

OK... The Architecture and history of this beir garten is unmatched but....   The beer and service is sub-par.   We went on a Sunday and it wasn't all that busy yet and waited 45 mins to even get noticed at our table..  we ordered a beer which was OK but.. there are much better in Munich.. (see below) the waiter never really came back so we decided to go elsewhere..  we got the cash for out beers and handed it to the waiter and he was agitated because we were willing to wait another hour or so to eat..   so... We went across the street to Augustiner am Platzl and we were blown away.. hands down the best meal and beer in Munich.   We loved it so much we are there twice in 2 days..

After walking about 24,568 steps today we ventured into this fun lovely beer hall to sample our first German Beers which began our German Trip today.Quickly sat down at a table with other beer drinking visitors who were from Spain.  Tables are set up here to sit six to a table and enjoy each other's company while relieving painful feet.We ordered a Heifiweisen type beer and settled on a delicious sausage and potato salad lunch plate.  Large plates of pig knuckles and Wiener schnitzel where dancing before our eyes but we went with a little light fare.Everything was really good.  The menus were in German so we were not really sure what we were ordering.Great umpah music was playing in the background which added to the cheeryness  of the place.  One beer was plenty for us as we were off to the English Garden to see the surfers.

Not as fun as Oktoberfest but a great time anyway! I visited this place in the 90's and again in Aug of 2019. They do not miss a beat. A great time! Good food, entertainment and full of fun times. If you cant go to a festival then come here!!!!!!

Keeping this short because, well, das Original.  The history, atmosphere, location, beer, pretzels, and service may be duplicated in other cities (have been to the Las Vegas & Rosemont locations), but it feels different here.  Made several visits on my short trip to Munich and would encourage everyone to ignore the tourist warnings and visit Hofbräuhaus Munich.  It's a great experience, especially in a group.  Maybe not as much when alone, then it can be a bit overwhelming.

Five stars to HB for hanging around Munich since the late 1500s, surviving several wars, host several historical figures, serve traditional German food and know how to throw a party nightly for people around the world. If you have read a few of my reviews, you know that I just don't go somewhere to say I've been there and take a photo for social media. I like to find out more about a place, HB is no exception. To spare you a long History lesson about the place, I urge you to google the History of HB and appreciate it just not as a place to eat, have a bier and take pictures. From being the Royal bier and bier house of the Bavarian King when it opened to hosting figures as Lenin, Hiltler and Motzart, there is more than being a tourist trap in today's world. So I came here during Oktoberfest of this year, yes I'm a sucker for punishment. Full and packed, I knew we had to act fast to secure a table. We split up and I scored a table, texted my friend, flagged down my waitress and ordered. I knew I could be a lookie-loo after. Work smarter not harder!The food came quick and we ordered the sausage plate with spätzle to share. It's German food. I've had this dish a few times at the HB in Vegas plus other places in my trip. Now, I do have to say the pretzel was better than the ones in Vegas... Yes I know it's not as Fresh, duh. Bier was good.The people watching is fantastic here, ranks up there after Vegas on a Saturday night in July. The poor pretzel gals, they were always being lassoed into tourist pictures, so purchase a pretzel as she passes your table. If you have been to America's HBs, let me say this: This. Is. Germany. You aren't going to chicken dance, group sing "Caroline" or get paddled after a shot by your server in a drind'l. So yes, please go. Have a bier and Google the history.

Meh. This is a big time tourist spot. But my husband insisted. Huge place, fun band and cold beer. However, not really "fun". We didn't try the over priced food. Got a pretzel from the nice pretzel girl though. Been there, done that. Don't need to do it again.
Omph Pom pa was amazing had a lovely dinner here of course with the liter of Oktoberfest beer.   I always go here when I stop in Munich
What a fun place. The biergarden is great. The food is also very comforting. The service is fast and the beer is cold

We didn't have a reservation and we were seated relatively fast. The staff was much more accommodating and friendlier than the previous beer garden I had in Munich. Maybe it's different during lunch hours as dinner might be a little more hectic. This place is huge with multiple levels. Thank goodness we got to sit inside with heat. It was very relaxing. We of course got German beer again to try. I'm not much of a beer drinker so I don't have much to comment about it but it was definitely decent. One of the better beers I have enjoyed. I got the roasted pork knuckle and it was much better than the other beer garden. Skin was very crispy and seasoned very well. Their potato ball was also better tasting as it had more flavor. I also got to try the pickled pork knuckle which the other beer garden didn't seem to offer. It was also very good and actually more tender. I'd gladly get both if I come here again. I also tried to buy a beer glass here as well and the lovely staff told us to just go to the gift shop to buy it so it's guaranteed to be new and I can inspect and choose the glass I want myself. My other friend tried the ox roast and it was pretty dry and not tender. Try to not be so adventurous and stick to what foods should taste good and be relatively foolproof to cook. Last thing I want to order is something that isn't exactly a must order if you are in Germany.

The Famous Hofbrauhaus in Germany/Munich. Had to try it out, and it was definitely worth the visit. The food was great, as we tried an assortment of traditional German dishes. I liked the schnitzel the best. The beers are great and ended up getting a 1L chug without knowing. Good times, at a cool location near the city centre close to Marienplatz.

Go to Munich - go to Hofbrauhaus - get the Schweinshaxe - drink all the beer.  Very important instructions to follow. Don't expect high quality food, but definitely expect a high quality time! 2 stars for food, 5 stars for the classic experience.
A must see in Munich but the pretzels were very dry and the staff wasn't very friendly

So much fun. If you come from the states, remember that you don't need to wait to be seated. Just walk in and sit wherever you fit, as long as the table does not say "reserviert." They have menus in both English and German. Most nights the oompah band starts playing at 6:00.The food here is excellent. The pretzels are gigantic and tasty, the meats are well-prepared, and the service is quick. Of note, you need to signal the waiter when you want to order and when you want to pay. Definitely visit this historic location if you are visiting from the states.

You find your own seat at long picnic tables. Wait staff come over quickly to take your order. We loved the lemonade and beer in a huge liter beer mug. Potato soup and bratwurst were good. The giant pretzel was fun and great for getting the last of soup. Just go and have a good time meeting new people and enjoy Munich.

Tourist Trap? Absolutely! A must visit when in Munich? YES!Came here on my last night in Munich last Thursday. It was absolutely packed around 8:30 pm. Our party of 6 managed to snag a spot in the patio, which was really nice because the inside of the restaurant does not have A/C and we were there during the heat wave that was sweeping through Europe. It took a really long time for someone to come around and take our order, but they did have girls walking around selling these huge pretzels, so we weren't just sitting around hungry. We ordered some steins of beer and a pork knuckle to share. The beers and pretzels were good, of course, but the best part of our meal was the pork knuckle. The meat was so tender and flavored so well. We were all wonderfully surprised by this dish. It took a while for them to bring us the food, but it was well worth the wait.The atmosphere is really fun. They have a Om Pah band that plays in the restaurant (a little hard to hear if you sit outside). Everyone is really happy and having a great time.

Definitely a must-visit in Munich! However the novelty will not last multiple visits.The royal beer hall is well known for its beer and atmosphere, but I found the food lacking. We got the pork knuckle and the sausage platter. They were decent, but they're not great. The food came out lukewarm. The meat were tasty, but they would be more tasty if they were warmer. Especially when the beer is crisp and cold, the lukewarm food is not a great combo.I do not regret going, but I wouldn't visit again.
Excellent place for lunch  try also the Höfbräuhaus Original  just amazing . The live music  is a plus
Good food, meet new friends and drink plenty of bier. If in Munich, Germany you have to go!!'

This place is incredibly popular during Octoberfest. We were not here during Octoberfest and it was jammed packed at 10pm. It has a fun environment and musicians who move around to different areas. It is something everyone should experience at least once in their life. It is very warm inside with the hundreds of people laughing, eating, drinking and having a great time.

Because of the large crowd, good service is hard to give & get. The wait staff is running raged. It is hard to get the attention of the wait staff to place an order and to get the bill. There are employees dressed in traditional Bavarian outfits selling large pretzels & cookies. The dark beer is tasty & refreshing. 1 litter is a lot of beer to finish in one seating. The roasted whole pork knuckle is pretty good. The meat & gravy are tasty, but the skin is hard. There is a lot of meat in a knuckle, enough for 2 adults. The potato dumpling is plain. All side dishes such salad, sauerkraut, etc. must be ordered separatedly. I am neutral about this restaurant.

A must go to if you are visiting Munich.  The beer is good, the venue enormous and historic.  The pretzels are great and gigantic.  The bratwurst is satisfying.  Potato gratin great.  Service is quick.  If you come at the right time there will even be a band playing.

It's iconic and a neat place to go, to be in a space that holds so much history. The seating is confusing, just find a seat and sit down, they will come take your order and be ready to pay when served, they do not run tabs. The food comes out quick and while waiting there are pretzels going around.

What else is there to say? It's the original!! The girl serving us seemed kind of busy/annoyed, but it was Oktoberfest so it made sense. She was over the tourists. Food was good (for what we ordered) and of course the beer. The live music is always a great time!  Kase Spätzle has to be one of my favorite foods on the entire planet. Theirs also had some tasty onions right on top.
What can I say? It's Hofbräuhaus! Tons of history, great service, and best of all, great beer! Who can go to Munich and not stop?

Actually 3.5.  Stopped by this famous tourist attraction for a liter of beer.  First time I came by was at night and it was crowded.  It looked like people were really enjoying themselves but the inside was hot and stuffy.  The outside patio in the center was closing so I couldn't enjoy a beer there.  Came by the next day for a beer and large pretzel from one of the roving pretzel servers.  Beer was okay but good for German style standards.  I'm a West coast IPA guy and not a fan for these styles of beer.  Pretzel was okay.  I wish they were warm.  Ambience is fun and inviting.  There was live music which added nicely to the ambiance.

Great place with tasty German food and a friendly neighborhood vibe! I came here for a beer and the pork shoulder, and it was quite delicious! There's a live band and you share communal tables with people around you. The downside is that it is a very touristy area, with people who just go in for pictures and not for food. Also, the prices are slightly higher than many places around the area. Overall, the experience is great for tourists who are not spending too much time in Munich! The food is extremely filling and tasty, and the beer goes down quite well. Definitely recommend if you are okay with overpaying a little!

It's touristy, it's loud, it's crowded, but ya gotta do it if you're coming to Munich. Day one in Germany: we're jetlagged, smelling like planes, and in need of a nap. Instead we set out on foot to the Hofbrauhaus after wandering the city. We wandered the restaurant for about 5 minutes when a 4 person table opened up and our three large butts plopped down.  We waited maybe another 2 minutes before menus were slid into our chubby hands and maybe another 15 minutes passed when we decided what we wanted. What can I say? Our brains were still bogged down with travel itineraries and other miscellaneous American pointlessness. Some more time goes by and then our XL radlers are placed in our still chubby hands and here is where I leave my mortal body and ascend into heaven.  Slightly sweet, incredibly refreshing, and that aura of beer enters my bloodstream and my California brain forgets about the snow outside (that's right, it snowed). Then a super hot woman in traditional Oktoberfest gear saunters up to our table with two XXL pretzels and I reach spiritual nirvana. I black out and somehow buy a pretzel from her. She only accepts cash, I DGAF. Our meals are float to us and here is what I remember of my spaetzle: it's one of their few vegetarian options, it's cheesy and delicious, and it's topped with fried onions. It goes amazingly with my radler and I can't imagine ever being hungry again. I snagged my chub-hub's sauerkraut cuz he hates it, I love it. We all over-ordered, but we all left happy, rosy, and wondering why the heck it can't be Oktoberfest all year long.  Too much of a good thing? Nah, it's the German experience you're looking for.

Go for the atmosphere and the fun! The food is decent, but the experience is what is really the draw at Hofbrauhaus. We sat with a group of young guys from Russia who were happy to share their table and some conversation with us. I love this about Germany that everyone seems a part of one community when enjoying a good meal and beer! We sat upstairs where they had a band and dancers. The menu was limited upstairs, but included their most popular traditional Bavarian dishes. Our server was very prompt and efficient. Prices were reasonable.
Must visit fun atmosphere for tourists!  I cam here and bought a stein too haha. Ppl were singing and it made me really experience the culture
The drinks were perfectly suggested according to our likes. The food was so delicious that I forgot to take pics. I did the veal with a side of mushroom sauce. I'll be back.

Gets crowded quickly. One visit is all you need to have the nostalgic feeling of a traditional German Beer hall. A bit touristy but the beer is still good!! Great place to get a few souvenirs for friends back home.It's loud crowded and difficult to get great service. In Germany you just sit down and wait for the server. Be ready to order since they may not be back for a while. I prefer the dark or dunkel and my husband liked the lighter. Bottoms up!! Brost!!

Even if you don't like beer, just come here anyway to be able to say that you've experienced it. Came here on a Monday evening and it was completely packed. It was hot in the main dining area. Luckily they had outside seating. I ordered the half roasted chicken that came with potato salad. My husband ordered pork belly. We also shared a side bowl of red cabbage. And of course we each ordered Radlers. Total bill came to less than 50 euros.

Classic but touristy.The essence of Oktoberfest is maintained here for the rest of the year. Of course you have to try the original Hofbrau beer. I enjoyed the lemonade-beer mix, too. Even and especially on a cold, short, rainy December day, the warm and cheerful atmosphere of Hofbräuhaus was amplified by the lively music, colorful ceiling art, and all the people there at all hours of the day. A must-visit! Don't be surprised to find yourself dining next to amiable strangers--all for the love of beer!

Walk in the door and you're hit by the Oom-pah music playing and you can feel that Polka start to tingle in your bones. Yes everybody has a little bit of that folk or Volkstümliche Musik in the blood. Next thing you know you're looking for, finding a table and a waitress who reminded me of someone from the movie Heidi, is passing out a round of beer in giant mugs.  I'm sitting with my traveling companions, a colonel and major when someone comes over and tells the major that the table we're sitting at is one of the family tables. I look around and now I notice some of these table booths have what I figure are family crests over them and maybe at certain times, like these busy nights, they're reserved for local families. Probably for years.The major leans over and tells the colonel about it suggest that we move.  But the colonel isn't having any of that. He's enjoying his beer, smiling and listening to the music while he looks over the menu.  We're getting some strange looks from a couple of folk at the nearby tables and I'm thinking, oh Lord this colonel's about to start an international incident.  But as it turns out when some of the family members DO show up, they wanted us to stay and it turned into a good time with good company and good food.  The music was playing, people were singing, beer mugs were hitting against the table, the pork and pretzels was coming out.  It was freezing outside but it was nice and warm where we were sitting.  Beer is in important and historic food group in Germany and there was plenty to be had.   When we were finished, got up and walked around, that's when we noticed that there was an even larger dinner hall room where the majority of the tourist were seated.  The major looked at me and said that's probably where we were supposed to be!  I mean the place was packed! If you ever get to Germany you have to make a stop here and order up some cheer.

If you like beer, Hofbrauhaus is a must visit. The seating is unique, and unlike most places in the US, so it encourages you meeting neighbors, which brings you together with people from all over the world- especially after a few of the big mug beers! Or, go out back and enjoy your beeer on the patio overlooking a square. Amazing history to this venue and a story to be told at every corner. Highly recommend giving this place a try.

Awesome place! Love the beer and food. The environment is lively, fun, and loud. Seating is a bit different. Find a spot or ask people if you can sit with them. We met a nice couple who help us with the beer and food...gave us really good suggestions because they had been there before. The band plays often. There's not a limit on how long you can sit there but you do have to order food or drinks. Again love this place

Come here for the experience, not the food. This is a massive temple to German beer. I didn't see the whole place but there are multiple floors and so many different dining rooms.... it's pretty spectacular. Everyone is drinking beer and having a good time. They didn't let me order any increments smaller than a liter of beer.

5 STAR FOREVER!!!!!!!!!!!Hofbrauhaus:  U-L-T-I-M-A-T-E REVIEW!!!!!!!!!!!!!!First things first, know your history.The Hofbräuhaus am Platzl, Munich's famous "hofbrauhaus", was founded in 1589 by the Duke of Bavaria, Wilhelm V.  It is one of Munich's oldest beer halls.  It was founded as the brewery to the old Royal Residence, which at that time was situated just around the corner from where the beer hall stands today.Even the Royals wanted to live near the Hofbrauhaus, which is why I booked my hotel during my nearly two week stay in Munich to be as close to the Hofbrauhaus as possible.Additional history:  Some little Austrian used to speak here too, I think he killed himself, or moved to Argentina, anyways.This is the place to meet friends, family, even enjoy by yourself.  Some of people's biggest complaints are also it's most powerful strong points, The Hofbrauhaus is Munich's cultural center, therefore, many people, including locals and tourists are here at pretty much all times.For someone as social as me, I absolutely LOVE IT that it's packed and full of new people to chat with and look at.People from all over the world come here, so it's pretty much an international embassy.Also, and let's not gloss over this fact, the food and beer are some of the best you are ever to enjoy on your time on this Planet.  I wouldn't be surprised if many people's parting thoughts from this mortal coil are of good times at The Hofbrauhaus.But I digress, and in addition, would love to mention the amazingly talented oompah band!!!On one of my visits, they set up right next to my table in the outdoor courtyard, and I had the pleasure of listening to them live for an hour straight.Can you say HEAVEN!!!God, this place is one of a kind, so genuine, and the staff is super on point as well, especially given how many people they are waiting on at once.  The service has blown my mind given all the variables.  These people are extremely intelligent, on point, and well organized and managed.THE BEER, THE BEER, THE BEER!!!Order it, and keep it coming, this is not a place to come to for one drink, although many people do, and there is nothing wrong with that, but I have found that just posting up for 3 or 4 straight hours, over 3 or 4 liters is the way to go.Before you know it, you're all charged up, feeling great, and ready to take on the rest of Munich, or a nap!!!Either way, whether it's for one beer, or a bunch, or a plate of amazing food, The Hofbrauhaus is a life changing experience, and most of the humans who have entered it's doors, have remembered it for the rest of their lives.Thank you Hofbrauhaus, for existing, for loving me, and for allowing me to love you.I LOVE YOU!!!!!!!!!!!

Yeah, I know that this place is an institution, and I know that I am only going on my first impressions from a few years back, and I also know that this place literally defines Munich, but honestly, I really didn't like it. I guess it really had a lot to do with the fact that it was just so crowded and I really couldn't get the attention of any of the wait staff, and I certainly had no idea where I could go and get one of those massive beers that they seem to advertise about this place. Okay, I'd probably only come here for a beer considering that there is absolutely no way I could actually eat one of their massive meals. Sure, I probably should give this place another shot, if I ever end up back in Munich that is, and I probably should update my review if that happens, at the way it is now, it was crowded, and I really had no idea how long I was going to wait until I actually got served.
Nice exerience and they have their own brand-shop. The inner gardens is nice for food and drinks.

The whole roasted pork was very nice comparing with those I had tried. Dark beer was fresh so that you do not really taste the alcohol in, which made it really good with your foods. Also, the price was very reasonable. We ordered two dark beer, 1.01L, two pork, and one cheese noodle, and the total was €62.80. If you want to go to the dinning room instead of the beer house, you should call and make a reservation. I would recommend to go earlier since you will need to wait for a long time to have your foods come.

Good beer, good food, terrible service. The server must have hated his job. Everything landed on our table with a loud thud. If you're going go work at a place with many tourists, you need a better disposition. We still tipped as if we had decent service, although we considered otherwise.  If you're willing to take a chance on service, go to this place simply for thr beer and atmosphere.

We really liked this place! It's an institution, for sure. We felt like we couldn't very well come to Munich and not have a beer here, so we set out mid afternoon one day. It is HUGE - very cavernous place with tons of rooms, and it's very loud and a bit chaotic. It's important to note that when you walk in, you do not need to wait for/locate a hostess to be seated - you literally find a free seat somewhere and wedge your body into it. Service comes around when they can, and if there are a lot of people (which, let's face it, I'm unsure if this restaurant is ever NOT busy), it will take a little while - but try to be patient, if you can! The beer is worth it. Our waiter came around after waiting about 20 minutes - we watched him work in a clockwise fashion around what we deemed to be "his" service area, so I promise - they DO have a method, and they aren't ignoring you. We ordered two dark beers and some cheese spatzle to share. One of the nice things about a more touristy restaurant - he didn't bat an eye about us sharing. I have a pretty small appetite, especially when paired with a liter of beer, so we were appreciative of being able to split, which isn't usually a big thing in Europe. Will definitely be a repeat visit for us! Prost!
